ADOPTING ORDINANCES
ORDINANCE NO. 061-1985
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code for Nicholasville, Kentucky;
Establishing the Same; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not
Included Therein; Providing for the Manner of Amending and Supplementing Such
Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall Become Effective.
Now Therefore Be It Ordained by the City of Nicholasville:
   § 1.   The Code of Ordinances, consisting of Chapters 1 to 25, each
inclusive, is hereby adopted and enacted as the "Code of Ordinances, of the
City of Nicholasville, Kentucky," which Code shall supersede all general and
permanent ordinances of the City adopted on or before November 27, 1984, to the
extent provided in § 2 hereof.
   § 2.   All provisions of the Code shall be in full force and effect from and
after November 1, 1985, and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature
enacted on final passage on or before November 27, 1984, and not included in
the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein are hereby
repealed from and after such effective date.
   § 3.   The repeal provided for in § 2 hereof shall not be construed to
revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent
ordinance which is repealed by this ordinance.
   § 4.   Whenever in such Code, or in any ordinance of the City, any act or
omission is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor,
or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act or the failure to do
any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor or is prohibited, and no
specific penalty is provided therefor, and state law does not provide
otherwise, or for a greater penalty, the violation of any such provision of
such Code or any ordinance shall be a misdemeanor punishable by a term of
imprisonment of up to thirty (30) days in jail or a fine of up to five hundred
dollars ($500.00) but not less than ten dollars ($10.00), or both fine and
imprisonment. Unless specifically provided otherwise, or the context thereof so
dictates, each day any violation of any provisions of this Code or any
ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense
   § 5.   Any and all additions and amendments to the Code, when passed in the
form as to indicate the intention of the city commission to make the same part
of the Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference
to the Code shall be understood and intended to include the additions and
amendments.
   § 6.   In case of the amendment of any section of the Code for which a
penalty is not provided, the general penalty, as provided in § 4 of this
ordinance, and in §§ 1-10 of the Code shall apply to the section as amended, or
in case the amendment contains provisions for which a penalty, other than the
aforementioned general penalty, is provided in another section in the same
chapter, the penalty so provided in the other section shall be held to relate
to the section so amended, unless specifically repealed therein.
   § 7.   All ordinances adopted after November 27, 1984, which amend or refer
to ordinances which have been codified in the Code shall be construed as if
they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code.
   § 8.   This ordinance and the Code adopted hereby, shall become effective
November 1, 1985.
FIRST READING
DATED OCTOBER 8, 1985

ORDINANCE NO. 232-97
An Ordinance Enacting and Adopting a Supplement to the Code of Ordinances of
the City of Nicholasville, Kentucky.
   Whereas, Burlington Publishing Systems, Florence, Kentucky, has completed
the S-11 Supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of Nicholasville,
which supplement contains all ordinances of a general nature enacted since the
adoption of the S-10 Supplement to the Code of Ordinances of this municipality;
and
   Whereas, said Burlington Publishing Systems has recommended the revision or
addition of certain sections of the Code of Ordinances which are based on or
make reference to sections of the Kentucky code; and
   Whereas, it is the intent of the Commission to accept these updated sections
in accordance with the changes of the law of the Commonwealth of Kentucky;
   Now, therefore, be it ordained by the City Commission of the City of
Nicholasville, Commonwealth of Kentucky:
   § 1.   That the S-11 Supplement to the Code of Ordinances of the City of
Nicholasville, as submitted by Burlington Publishing Systems, and as attached
hereto, be and the same is hereby adopted by reference as if set out in its
entirety.
   § 2.   That this ordinance shall take effect and be in force from and after
its date of passage.
                  /s/   Sam E. Corman
                     Mayor
ATTEST:   /s/   Bonnie Dean
         City Clerk
Date of First Reading:      September 25, 1997
Date of Second Reading:      October 9, 1997

Chapter 1 GENERAL PROVISIONS
Sec. 1-1. HOW CODE DESIGNATED AND CITED.
   The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections
shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of Ordinances, City of
Nicholasville, Kentucky," and may be so cited.
(Code 1972, § 1-1)
   State law reference-Codification authority, KRS 83A.060(5).
Sec. 1-2. DEFINITIONS AND RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   Generally, this Code and all ordinances of the city shall be liberally
construed with a view to promote their objects and carry out the intent of the
city commission.
   In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it
shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the
public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any
provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than
the general provisions imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater
restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling.
   All words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and
approved usage of language, but technical words and phrases, and such others as
may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law, shall be
construed according to such meaning.
   City. The words "city" or "this city" mean the City of Nicholasville,
Kentucky.
   City commission. The words "city commission" mean the city commission of
Nicholasville, Kentucky.
   Code. The words "this Code" or "this Code of Ordinances" shall mean the Code
of Ordinances, City of Nicholasville, Kentucky, as designated in §
1-1, and as hereinafter modified by amendment, revision and by the adoption of
new chapters or sections.
   Computation of time.  
   (a)   In computing any period of time prescribed or allowed by order of
court, by any applicable statute or regulation, or this Code, the day of the
act, event or default after which the designated period of time begins to run
is not to be included. The last day of the period so computed is to be
included, unless it is a Saturday, a Sunday, a legal holiday, or a day on which
the public office in which a document is required to be filed is actually and
legally closed, in which event the period runs until the end of the next day
which is not one of the days just mentioned. When the period of time prescribed
or allowed is less than seven (7) days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays, and
legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation.
   (b)   When an act is required to be done either a certain time before an
event or a certain time before the day on which an event occurs, the day of the
event shall be excluded in computing the time. If the day thereby computed on
which or by which the act is required to be done falls on a Saturday, Sunday,
legal holiday, or a day on which the public office in which the act is required
to be completed is actually and legally closed, the act may be done on the next
day which is none of the days just mentioned.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.030.
   County. Whenever the words "the county" or "this county" are used, they
shall refer to Jessamine County, Kentucky.
   Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring an officer
or head of a department of the city to do some act or make certain inspections,
it is to be construed to authorize the officer or head of the department to
designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or
make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section
designate otherwise.
   Executive order. An order issued by the Commission which is binding upon the
officers and employees of the city and any governmental agency over which the
city has jurisdiction.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 83A.010(7).
   Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only may extend and be applied
to females as well as males.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.020(2).
   Joint authority. Words giving authority to three (3) or more officers or
other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such
officers or other persons.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.050.
   KRS. The abbreviation "KRS" or phrase "Revised Statutes" refer to the
Revised Statutes of Kentucky, as amended.
   Land or real estate. The words "land" and "real estate" include lands,
tenements and hereditaments and all rights thereto and interest therein, other
than a chattel interest.
   State law reference–Similar provisions, KRS 446.010(23).
   May. The word "may" is permissive.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.010(26).
   Misdemeanor. An offense for which the criminal fine can not exceed the
amount set forth in KRS 534.040(2)(a), or a term of imprisonment not to exceed
the periods set forth in KRS 532.090(1), or both.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 83A.065.
   Month. The word "month" means a calendar month.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.010(27).
   Municipal order. An official act of the city commission which is binding
upon the officers and employees of the city and any governmental agency over
which the municipality has jurisdiction.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 83A.010(9).
   Name or title of officer, board, commission or agency. The name or title of
any officer, board, commission or agency, when appearing alone herein, shall be
construed as if the words "of Nicholasville, Kentucky," followed it. It shall
include any authorized subordinate or designee.
   Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied
to several persons or things, as well as to one (1) person or thing, and a word
importing the plural number only may extend and be applied to one (1) person or
thing as well as to several persons or things.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.020(1).
   Oath. The word "oath" includes "affirmation" in all cases in which an
affirmation may be substituted for an oath.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.010(28).
   Officer. Any person elected to a position by the voters or any person
appointed to a position which:
   (a)   Is created by the Constitution, the General Assembly, or a city;
   (b)   Possesses a delegation of a portion of the sovereign power of
government;
   (c)   Has powers and duties to be discharged which are conferred directly or
by implication by the city;
   (d)   Has duties performed independently and without control of a superior
power other than the law;
   (e)   Has some permanency;
   (f)   Requires an official oath;
   (g)   Is assigned by a commission or other written authority; and
   (h)   Provides for an official bond if required by proper authority.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 83A.010(10).
   Ordinance. An official act of a city legislative body, which is a regulation
of a general and permanent nature and enforceable as a local law or is an
appropriation of money.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 83A.010(11).
   Owner. The word "owner," applied to buildings or land, includes any part
owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety,
of the whole or of a part of such building or land.
   Partnership. Includes both general and limited partnerships.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.010(30).
   Person. May extend and be applied to bodies-politic and corporate,
societies, communities, the public generally, individuals, partnerships,
registered limited liability partnerships, joint stock companies, and limited
liability companies.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.010(33).
   Personal property. "Personal property" includes money, goods, chattels,
things in action and evidence of debt.
   Property. "Property" includes both real and personal property.
   Public place. "Public place" means any public way, park, cemetery, school
yard or open space adjacent thereto; any public lake or stream; and any place
or business open to the use of the public in general.
   Shall. The word "shall" is mandatory.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.010(39).
   Signature or subscription. "Signature" or "subscription" includes a mark,
the name being written near the mark and witnessed.
   State. The word "state" means the Commonwealth of Kentucky.
   Street. The word "street" means and includes any public way, road, highway,
street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley, lane, viaduct, bridge and the
approaches thereto within the city.
   Sworn. The word "sworn" includes "affirmed" in all cases in which an
affirmation may be substituted for an oath.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.010(43).
   Tenant. The words "tenant" and "occupant," applied to a building or land,
include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land,
whether alone or with others.
   Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as
the past and present.
   Violate. Includes failure to comply.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.010(47).
   Violation. An offense for which the criminal fine can not exceed the amount
set forth in KRS 534.010(2)(c).
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 83A.065.
   Writing. The words "writing" and "written" including printing, typewriting,
engraving, lithography and any other mode of representing words and letters.
   Year. The word "year" means calendar year.
   State law reference–Similar provisions, KRS 446.010(49).
(Code 1972, § 1-2)
Sec. 1-3. HEADINGS, NOTES AND REFERENCES.
   Chapter, article, division, section and subsection heads or titles, and
explanatory notes, cross references and state law references, in this Code, do
not constitute any part of the law, except as otherwise expressly provided.
(Code 1972, § 1-3)
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.140.
Sec. 1-4. EFFECT OF REPEAL OF AN ORDINANCE.
   (a)   The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force
before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect.
   (b)   The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty
incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding
pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance
repealed.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.100, 446.110.
Sec. 1-5. MISCELLANEOUS ORDINANCES NOT AFFECTED BY CODE.
   Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be deemed to
affect the validity of any of the following ordinances when not inconsistent
with this Code, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in
full force and effect under their own terms and conditions:
      (1)   Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for
the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence
of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city;
      (2)   Any ordinance authorizing the execution of agreements with other
governments or agencies;
      (3)   Any personnel and pay classification plan or other ordinance or
part of an ordinance fixing salaries and other benefits of officers or
employees of the city;
      (4)   Any appropriation ordinance;
      (5)   Any right or franchise granted to any person;
      (6)   Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating,
relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or
public way in the city;
      (7)   Any ordinance establishing and prescribing the street grades of any
street in the city;
      (8)   Any ordinance providing for local improvements or assessing taxes
therefor;
      (9)   Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in
the city, or providing regulations for the same;
      (10)   Any ordinance annexing property to the city;
      (11)   Any zoning ordinance of the city;
      (12)   Any annual tax levy;
      (13)   Any ordinance prescribing traffic regulations for specific
locations, prescribing through streets, parking limitations, parking
prohibitions, one-way traffic, limitations on loads of vehicles or loading
zones or flow of traffic generally;
      (14)   Any temporary or special ordinance.
Sec. 1-6. SEVERABILITY.
   It shall be considered that it is the intent of the city commission, in
enacting this Code or any ordinance, that if any part of the Code or ordinance
be held unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable, the remaining parts shall
remain in force, unless the Code or ordinance provides otherwise, or unless the
remaining parts are so essentially and inseparably connected with and dependent
upon the unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable part that it is apparent
that the city commission would not have enacted the remaining parts without the
unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable part, or unless the remaining parts,
standing alone, are incomplete and incapable for being executed in accordance
with the intent of the city commission.
(Code 1972, § 1-5)
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 446.090.
Sec. 1-7. AMENDMENTS TO CODE; EFFECT OF NEW ORDINANCES; AMENDATORY LANGUAGE.
   (a)   All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code of Ordinances which
amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code of Ordinances, may be numbered in
accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion
herein. In the case of repealed chapters, articles, divisions, sections and
subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed
portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages
affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted,
in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent
ordinances until such time that this Code of Ordinances and subsequent
ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the
city commission.
   (b)   Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by
amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this
Code in the following language:
   "That section ___________ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Nicholasville,
Kentucky, is hereby amended to read as follows: . . . ." The provisions shall
be set out in full as desired.
   (c)   If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added,
the following language may be used:
   "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Nicholasville, Kentucky, is hereby
amended by adding a section, to be numbered _____________, which said section
reads as follows: . . . " The new section shall then be set out in full as
desired.
   (d)   All sections, divisions, articles, chapters or provisions desired to
be repealed shall be specifically repealed by section, division, article or
chapter number, as the case may be.
(Code 1972, § 1-6)
Sec. 1-8. SUPPLEMENTATION OF CODE.
   (a)   By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be
prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city commission. A
supplement to the Code shall include all substantive parts of permanent and
general ordinances passed by the city commission during the period covered by
the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a
supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and
will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially
obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been
inserted the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the
latest ordinance included in the supplement.
   (b)   In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which
have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from
reprinted pages.
   (c)   When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the
person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make
formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included
in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a
unified code. For example, the codifier may:
      (1)   Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions;
      (2)   Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections
and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes
in such catchlines, headings and titles;
      (3)   Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be
inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change
existing section or other subdivision numbers;
      (4)   Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to
"this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or
to "§§ ________ to ________," inserting section numbers to indicate the
sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance
incorporated into the Code;
      (5)   Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the
original meaning of the ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no
case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance
material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code.
Sec. 1-9. ALTERING CODE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by
additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or
delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any
manner whatsoever, except by ordinance or resolution or other official act of
the city commission, which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented
thereby.
(Code 1972, § 1-7)
   State law reference-Tampering with public records, KRS 519.060.
Sec. 1-10. GENERAL PENALTY; CONTINUING VIOLATIONS; ABATEMENT.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with
any provision of this Code, and where no specific penalty is provided therefor,
the violation of any provision of this Code shall be punished by a fine not
exceeding two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not less than ten dollars
($10.00).
   (b)   In addition to the penalties provided for in subsection (a), any
violation or condition which constitutes a nuisance may be abated by the city.
(Code 1972, § 1-8)
   State law reference-Penalty for violation of municipal ordinance not to be
less than that imposed by statute for same offense, Ky. Const. § 168;
publication of ordinances imposing fines, forfeitures, imprisonment, taxes or
fees, KRS 83A.060.

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Secs. 2-1--2-100. RESERVED.
ARTICLE II. CITY COMMISSION*
   *State law references-Legislative body, KRS 83A.030; form and procedure for
enacting ordinances, KRS 83A.060; commission plan, KRS 83A.140.
Sec. 2-101. ADOPTION OF NONPARTISAN ELECTIONS.
   The provisions of KRS 83A.170, providing for nonpartisan elections as
defined and prescribed in the aforesaid statute are hereby adopted.  All
elections shall be held in accordance with all provisions contained in KRS
83A.170.
(Ord. No. 9-B-80, 9-24-80)
Sec. 2-102. Assignment of commissioners.
   (a)   The City Commissioners shall select their desired departments as
defined by Article V. Departments in descending sequence by the number of votes
received in the general or local election. (For example; the Commissioner with
the most votes shall receive his or her first choice of desired department, the
Commissioner with the second most votes shall have his or her choice of
departments remaining after that, etc.) The City Commissioners may choose from
the departments enumerated from (1) through (4) under Article V, §
2-521 . The Mayor of the City of Nicholasville shall have primary
responsibility for five (5) Administrative Departments, absent a different
agreement between the Mayor and Commissioners confirmed by resolution.
   (b)   In the event that two (2) Commissioners receive the same number of
votes, the Commissioner having served longer as a Commissioner of the City of
Nicholasville shall have priority in selecting responsibility for the
department of his or her choice.
   (c)   In the event that two (2) Commissioners, receiving the same number of
votes, have the same amount of experience as a City Commissioner for the City
of Nicholasville OR in which neither Commissioner has any experience as a City
Commissioner for the City of Nicholasville, then the tie shall be resolved by a
coin toss administered by the Mayor of the City of Nicholasville. In such an
event, the Commissioner whose last name comes first alphabetically may declare
"heads" or "tails", such declaration to occur before the coin is tossed.
(Ord. No. 030-2021, 1-11-21)
Sec. 2-103. Salary.
   (a)   Effective January 1, 2007, the salary for the Mayor shall be thirty-
two thousand six hundred twelve dollars and eighty-eight cents ($32,612.88) per
annum and the salary for each Commissioner shall be twenty thousand six hundred
five dollars and twenty cents ($20,605.20) per annum.
   (b)   The annual salaries of the Mayor and each Commissioner may be
increased, pursuant to the provisions of KRS 83A.075, based on the change in
the consumer price index as determined by the Department of Local Government.
Said increases require a vote by the Nicholasville City Commission.
(Code 1972, §§ 2-7, 2-8; Ord. No. 4-A-81, 4-28-81; Ord. No. 030-2021, 1-11-21)
   State law reference-Salaries to be set each election year, KRS 83A.070.
Sec. 2-104. Regular meetings.
   (a)   The city commission shall meet twice a month on the second and fourth
Monday of each month, at the hour of 5:00 p.m., at the Nicholasville Police
Department’s Community Room located at 717 North Main Street.
   (b)   If the day set for a regular meeting falls on a legal holiday, such
meeting shall be automatically postponed until the next regular meeting.
(Code 1972, §§ 2-4--2-6; Ord. No. 7-G-80, 7-22-80; Ord. No. 1-A-82, § 1, 1-26-
82; Ord. No. 03-1984, 1-24-84; Ord. No. 069-1986, 1-28-86; Ord. No. 188-1988,
§§ 1-3, 1-15-88; Ord. No. 196-1988, §§ 1-3, 4-26-88; Ord. No. 003-1990, 1-23-
90; Ord. No. 008-1990, 1-30-90; Ord. No. 001-1992, 1-28-92; Ord. No. 042-1993,
6-25-93; Ord. No. 073-1994, §§ 1, 2, 1-11-94; Ord. No. 442-2003, 4-17-03; Ord.
No. 688-2008, 2-28-08; Ord. No. 731-2009, 4-23-09; Ord. 073-2022, 5-23-22)
   State law reference-Mandate for regular meetings, KRS 83A.140(7).
Sec. 2-105. Workshop.
   The city commission shall hold a workshop one (1) time per month on the
first Monday of each month, at 5:00 p.m. at the Nicholasville Police
Department’s Community Room located at 717 North Main Street.
(Ord. No. 089-1994, 7-14-94; Ord. No. 442-2003, 4-17-03; Ord. No. 688-2008, 2-
28-08; Ord. No. 731-2009, 4-23-09; Ord. 073-2022, 5-23-22)
Secs. 2-106–2-205. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. OFFICERS*
   *State law references-Elective officers, KRS 83A.040; creation of
nonelective city offices, KRS 83A.080; establishment of appointive offices, KRS
83A.140(8).
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
§ 2-206. APPOINTIVE OFFICERS SPECIFIED.
   The following officers shall be appointed to their respective offices by the
city commission and not by the voters of the city, with the exception of the
local alcoholic beverage control administrator who shall be appointed by the
mayor, and shall serve without tenure:
      (1)   City administrator;
      (2)   City attorney;
      (3)   City clerk;
      (4)   City treasurer;
      (5)   Local alcoholic beverage control administrator.
(Code 1972, § 2-3)
   State law references-Creation of nonelective city offices by ordinance, KRS
83A,080; establishment of appointive offices, KRS 83A.140(8).
§ 2-207. RESPONSIBLE TO MAYOR.
   The city treasurer, city clerk, city attorney and city administrator shall
be responsible to the mayor who shall prescribe their duties in addition to
their existing functions and duties presently prescribed by ordinance and
statute.
(Ord. No. 1-D-82, 1-27-82)
Secs. 2-208--2-225. RESERVED.
DIVISION 2. CITY ADMINISTRATOR†
   †State law references-Authority to delegate responsibility to a city
administrative officer, KRS 83A.140(6); city administrative officer, KRS
83A.090.
§ 2-226. OFFICE CREATED.
   There is hereby created the office of city administrator.
(Code 1972, § 2-37)
§ 2-227. QUALIFICATIONS.
   Qualifications for the city administrator shall be determined by the city
commission. Such qualifications shall include but not be limited to
professional training and experience in administration sufficient to ensure
competence.
(Code 1972, § 2-37)
§ 2-228. OATH; COMPENSATION; BOND.
   Prior to taking office the city administrator shall take an oath of office.
The compensation and bond shall be determined by the city commission.
(Code 1972, § 2-37)
§ 2-229. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   (a)   The duties and responsibilities of the city administrator shall
include, but not be limited to the following:
      (1)   Advise the city commission in policy formulation on overall
problems of the city;
      (2)   Have major responsibility for preparation and administration of
operating and capital improvement budgets under direction of the city
commission;
      (3)   Advise the city commission in the appointment of subordinate
administrative personnel if not delegated appointment authority by appropriate
order; and
      (4)   Have continuing direct relationships with operating department
heads on implementation and administration of programs.
   (b)   The city administrator shall carry out all additional duties lawfully
delegated by appropriate order of the city commission and shall have the same
powers as the city commission in carrying out such duties.
(Code 1972, § 2-38)
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 83A.090.
Secs. 2-230--2-245. RESERVED.
DIVISION 3. CITY ATTORNEY
§ 2-246. OFFICE CREATED.
   There is hereby created the office of city attorney.
§ 2-247. OATH; COMPENSATION; BOND.
   Prior to taking office the city attorney shall take an oath of office. The
salary of the city attorney shall be fixed at eight hundred eighty-five dollars
($885.00) per month, effective retroactively to July 5, 1989. The bond shall be
determined by the city commission.
(Code 1972, § 2-10(a); Ord. No. 4-B-81, § 2, 4-28-81; Ord. No. 084-1986, 3-25-
86; Ord. No. 029-1989, 8-8-89)
§ 2-248. ATTENDANCE AT COMMISSION MEETINGS.
   The city attorney shall attend the meetings of the city commission.
(Code 1972, § 2-10(b); Ord. No. 4-B-81, § 1, 4-28-81)
§ 2-249. LEGAL ADVISOR.
   The city attorney shall serve as legal advisor to the city commission. He
shall prepare and review all ordinances and necessary resolutions for the
approval of the commission. He shall further represent the city in litigation
either as plaintiff or defendant and make a diligent effort at all times to see
that the best interests of the city are upheld. In the event of litigation or
preparation for same, delinquent property tax litigation, work on public works
projects, and any other extraordinary services, the city attorney shall be
compensated over and above the above monthly salary on a per unit basis
according to normal charges of practicing attorneys.
(Code 1972, § 2-10(d))
§ 2-250. SERVICE AS DELINQUENT TAX COLLECTOR.
   The city attorney shall serve as delinquent tax collector for all property
taxes that become delinquent. The city treasurer shall turn over to the city
attorney's office all delinquent taxes for the previous property tax year on
March first (1st). The city attorney will then promptly seek to recover all
such taxes and is authorized to use whatever legal process including the
instigation of a lawsuit if necessary, to collect same. All taxes collected by
the city attorney will be promptly paid to the city treasurer for proper
credit. The city attorney shall be additionally paid a fee of twenty-five (25)
percent of all delinquent property taxes, penalty and interest paid after March
first (1st) for the previous tax year but a minimum of seventy-five dollars
($75.00) per tax bill. If litigation is required the court shall determine and
order a reasonable attorney fee for the city attorney service rendered in the
collection of the tax.
(Code 1972, § 2-10(e)) (Ord. No. 775-2009, 1-11-10)
Secs. 2-251--2-265. RESERVED.
DIVISION 4. CITY CLERK*
   *State law references-Office of city clerk required, KRS 83A.085.
§ 2-266. OFFICE CREATED.
   There is hereby created the office of city clerk.
§ 2-267. OATH; COMPENSATION; BOND.
   Prior to taking office the city clerk shall take an oath of office. The
compensation and bond shall be determined by the city commission.
§ 2-268. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The duties and responsibilities of the city clerk shall include, but not be
limited to the following:
      (1)   Maintenance and safekeeping of the permanent records of the city;
      (2)   Performance of the duties required of the official custodian or
custodian pursuant to KRS 61.870-61.882;
      (3)   Possession of the seal of the city if used; and
      (4)   Performance of all duties and responsibilities required of the city
clerk by statute or ordinance.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 83A.085.
Secs. 2-269--2-285. RESERVED.
DIVISION 5. CITY TREASURER
§ 2-286. OFFICE CREATED.
   There is hereby created the office of city treasurer.
§ 2-287. OATH; COMPENSATION; BOND.
   Prior to taking office the city treasurer shall take an oath of office. The
compensation shall be five thousand eight hundred thirty dollars ($5,830.00)
annually, and bond shall be determined by the city commission. This
compensation shall begin and be effective retroactively to July 5, 1989.
(Ord. No. 083-1986, 3-25-86; Ord. No. 030-1989, 8-8-89)
§ 2-288. DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The duties and responsibilities of the city treasurer shall be as provided
by state law and the ordinances of the city.
Secs. 2-289--2-305. RESERVED.
DIVISION 6. ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE CONTROL ADMINISTRATOR*
   *Cross reference-Alcoholic beverages generally,
Chapter 3.
   State law reference-Mandate for an alcoholic beverage control administrator,
KRS 241.160 et seq.
§ 2-306. OFFICE CREATED.
   There is hereby created the office of alcoholic beverage control
administrator, to be appointed by the mayor.
(Code 1972, § 3-3; Ord. No. 1-B-82, 1-26-82)
§ 2-307. COMPENSATION; EXPENSES.
   The salary of the alcoholic beverage control administrator shall be four
hundred seventy-five dollars ($475.00) per month. He shall not be paid for his
necessary and reasonable travel expenses nor paid any out of pocket expenses as
the aforesaid salary is deemed sufficient to include compensation and expenses.
(Code 1972, § 3-4; Ord. No. 1-C-82, 1-26-82; Ord. No. 082-1986; Ord. No. 031-
1989, 8-8-89; Ord. No. 002-1990, 1-23-90; Ord. No. 576-2006, 2-9-06; Ord. No.
899-2014, 1-27-2014)
§ 2-308. OATH AND BOND.
   (a)   The alcoholic beverage control administrator, before entering upon his
duties as such, shall take the oath prescribed in § 228 of the Kentucky
Constitution, and shall execute a bond with a good corporate surety in the
penal sum of not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00).
   (b)   The administrator may require any city employee under his supervision
to execute a similar bond in such penal sum as he deems necessary.
   (c)   The cost of bonds given under this section shall be borne by the city.
(Code 1972, § 3-5)
§ 2-309. FUNCTIONS.
   The functions of the alcoholic beverage control administrator shall be the
same with respect to city licenses and regulations, as the functions of the
state alcoholic beverage control board with respect to state licenses and
regulations, except that no regulation adopted by the administrator may be less
stringent than the statutes relating to alcoholic beverage control, or than the
regulations of the board. No regulation of the administrator shall become
effective until it has been approved by the board.
(Code 1972, § 3-3; Ord. No. 1-B-82, 1-26-82)
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 241.190
§ 2-310. APPEALS FROM ADMINISTRATOR.
   Appeals from the orders of the alcoholic beverage control administrator may
be taken to the state alcoholic beverage control board, by filing with the
board within thirty (30) days a certified copy of the orders of the
administrator. Matters at issue shall be heard by the board as upon an original
proceeding. Appeals from orders of the administrator shall be governed by KRS
243.550 to 243.590.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 241.200.
Secs.. 2-311--2-415. RESERVED.
ARTICLE IV. PERSONNEL*
   *Cross reference-Any personnel and pay classification plan or other
ordinance or part of an ordinance fixing salaries and other benefits of
officers or employees of the city saved from repeal, §
1-5(3).
   Cross reference-Code of ethical conduct,
Art. XII.
§ 2-416. CLASSIFICATION PLAN, COMPENSATION PLAN AND POLICIES AND PROCEDURES.
   (a)   The classification plan, compensation plan, and policies and
procedures on file in the city clerk's office shall be the system of personnel
administration for the city.
   (b)   The classification plan, compensation plan, and policies and
procedures may be waived, altered or suspended only by a change of ordinance.
(Ord. No. 159-1996, 2-08-96; Ord. No. 220-1997; Ord. No. 1066-2019, 8-26-19)
   Editor's note-Ord. No. 104-1994, adopted 11-10-94, repealed Ord. No. 033-
1984; Ord. No. 220-1997, adopted 6-26-97, repealed Ord. No. 104-1994.
§ 2-417. REIMBURSEMENT FOR USE OF PERSONAL VEHICLES.
   All city employees shall be paid and/or reimbursed at the rate of twenty
cents ($.20) per mile for the use of their personal vehicles when used for city
business.
(Ord. No. 014-1984, 5-22-84)
§ 2-418. PARTICIPATION IN COUNTY EMPLOYEES RETIREMENT SYSTEM.
   (a)   The City of Nicholasville is hereby authorized to participate in the
county employees retirement system effective July 2, 1986, and all eligible
regular full-time employees of this municipality are hereby authorized and
directed to comply with the statutory requirements of this retirement system.
   (b)   All new employees for the City of Nicholasville from July 2, 1986
forward will mandatorily be covered by the county employees retirement system
under the Kentucky Retirement Systems as outlined in Chapter 61 of the Kentucky
Revised Statutes.
   (c)   All present employees of the City of Nicholasville as of June 30,
1986, will have the option to come under the county employees retirement
system.
   (d)   All city employees as of July 2, 1986, electing to be covered by the
county employees retirement system shall be given credit for all of their
eligible past service with the City of Nicholasville. All contributions
necessary to fund the account to and including July 2, 1986, of participating
employees shall be paid by the City of Nicholasville.
   (e)   The mayor of the City of Nicholasville is hereby authorized to execute
necessary contractual documents with all parties to perfect participation in
the aforesaid program.
(Ord. No. 102-1986, §§ 1--5, 6-24-86)
   Editor's note-Nonamendatory Ord. No. 102-1986, §§ 1--5, adopted June 24,
1986, has been codified herein at the discretion of the editor as § 2-418.
§ 2-419. DEFENSE OF CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES RELATIVE TO ACTION IN TORT.
   (a)   Definitions. For purposes of this section the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly requires a different meaning:
      (1)   Action in tort shall mean any claim for monetary damages based upon
negligence, intentional tort, nuisance, products liability and strict liability
and shall also include any wrongful death or survival-type action.
      (2)   Officer shall mean any elected official of the City of
Nicholasville.
      (3)   Employee shall mean all full and part-time employees of the City of
Nicholasville, including volunteer firefighters and auxiliary police officers,
if any, but shall not include any independent contractor or any employee,
agent, supplier or subcontractor of any independent contractor.
   (b)   Legal defense provided. Except as provided in §
2-419(e), the city shall, without cost to the officer or employee, provide for
the legal defense of any officer or employee in any action in tort arising out
of an act or omission occurring within the scope of the officer's or employee's
employment or public duties with the city.
   (c)   Independent representation. The city may provide for the defense of
any officer or employee through its own legal counsel or by employing
independent legal counsel or by purchasing insurance which requires the insurer
to defend. If the city defends through its own legal counsel and its legal
counsel determines that the interests of the officer or employee and the city
conflict, the city shall obtain written consent of the employee for such
representation or shall provide independent representation. An employee may
have his own legal counsel to assist in the defense at the expense of the
employee.
   (d)   Notice of claim; request for defense. Upon receiving service of a
summons and complaint in any action or tort brought against him, an officer or
employee shall, within ten (10) days of his receipt of service, give written
notice of the claim and make a request that the city provide a defense to the
action. The notice of claim and request for defense shall be filed with the
mayor.
   (e)   Refusal to provide defense; conditions. The city may refuse to provide
for the defense of any action in tort brought against an officer or employee of
the city if it determines and notifies the employee in writing that:
      (1)   The act or omission was not within the actual or apparent scope of
the employee's employment;
      (2)   The employee acted or failed to act because of fraud, malice or
corruption; or
      (3)   A timely request to defend was not made in accordance with §
2-419(d) of this section.
   (f)   Recovery of defense costs upon city's refusal to defend. If the city
refuses to provide an officer or employee with a defense and the officer or
employee provides his own defense, the officer or employee shall be entitled to
recover all necessary and reasonable costs of said defense from the city if the
act or omission is judicially determined to have arisen out of the actual or
apparent scope of the employee's employment and the employee is found to have
acted without fraud, malice or corruption.
   (g)   Payment of judgment. Subject to the limitations set forth in §
2-419(h) and (i) below and provided that the city shall not pay any award of
punitive or exemplary damages, the city shall pay any judgment rendered against
an officer or employee in any action in tort, or any compromise or settlement
of such action.
   (h)   Refusal to pay judgment, compromise or settlement; conditions. The
city may refuse to pay any judgment, compromise or settlement in any action in
tort against an officer or employee, or if the city pays any judgment,
compromise or settlement, it may recover from the officer or employee the
amount of such payment and the costs to defend, if:
      (1)   The officer or employee acted or failed to act because of fraud,
malice or corruption.
      (2)   The action was outside the actual or apparent scope of the
employee's employment;
      (3)   The employee willfully failed or refused to assist the defense of
the action; or
      4)   The employee compromised or settled the claim without the consent of
the legislative body of the city.
   (i)   Approval required for compromise or settlement. An officer or employee
who is being provided a defense in an action in tort by the city shall not
enter into any compromise or settlement of the action without the approval of
the legislative body of the city.
   (j)   Scope of defense. Nothing in the section shall be construed as a
waiver of any defense which the city may assert in any action in tort brought
against it of any officer or employee of the city. Defense by the city of any
action shall not be deemed an admission by the city that the acts or omissions
of the officer or employee which gave rise to the action in tort were within
the actual or apparent scope of the officer or employee's employment or public
duties with the city.
   Editor's note-Nonamendatory Ord. No. 108-1986, §§ 1-10, adopted September 9,
1986, has been codified herein at the discretion of the editor as § 2-419.
§ 2-420. SAFETY MANUAL ADOPTED.
   The city adopts a safety manual setting out safety regulations for its
employees. The manual, entitled "Safety Manual" and dated January 12, 1995, is
hereby adopted by reference as if fully set out herein. A full copy of the
manual is on file in the office of city clerk.
(Ord. No. 116-1995, 1-26-95)
Sec. 2-421. Background checks.
   All appointed offices shall be subject to background checks that may involve
any appointed position to the city. This includes but is not limited to the
following: city administrator, city attorneys, city clerk, city treasurer,
planning and zoning appointees, planning and zoning commission appointees,
board of adjustment appointees, code enforcement board members, ethics
committee members, historic committee members, alcoholic and beverage control
administrator. Background checks shall be done by the police department and
given to the board of commissioners for use in making its determination as to
appointment of said positions.
(Ord. No. 575-2006, 1-26-06)
Secs. 2-422--2-520. RESERVED.
ARTICLE V. DEPARTMENTS*
   *Editor's note-Ord. No. 064-1993, adopted Dec. 14, 1993, amended Art. V to

§ 2-521. ENUMERATED.
   The following departments are hereby created:
      (1)   Police and fire department;
      (2)   Water plant, sewer plant, distribution and collection department;
      (3)   Electric and meter department;
      (4)   Streets and cemetery department;
      (5)   Administrative departments (including finance and planning and
zoning).
(Ord. No. 064-1993, 12-14-93; Am. Ord. 357-2000, 11-20-00; Am. Ord. 1073-2019,
9- 25-19; Am. Ord. 029-2021, 1-11-21)
§ 2-522. POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS.
   The function of the police and fire department shall be to provide police
and fire protection for all of the City of Nicholasville. The department head
shall oversee the total operations of the police department and the fire
department. He or she shall make administrative decisions and regulations for
the different operations of all the employees employed in said department. It
shall likewise be the duty of the administrative head to provide regulations
for the operation and use of all the equipment used by the employees of the
fire and police departments. The department head shall from time to time report
to the commission the various activities of the police and fire employees as
may be required by the mayor and/or the city commission. The maintenance for
the buildings that house the equipment used by the police and fire department
shall likewise be under the supervision of the department head.
   Likewise, the department head shall review all expenditures and income that
may come into the city treasury as a result of the operation of the employees
in his respective department. He or she shall likewise approve all expenditures
prior to payment by the city treasurer.
(Ord. No. 064-1993, 12-14-93; Am. Ord. 029-2021, 1-11-21)
   Cross references-Fire department, §
8-21 et seq.; police department, §
15-21 et seq.
   State law reference-Mandate for administrative and service functions to be
classified under departments, KRS 83A.140(6).
§ 2-523. WATER PLANT, SEWER PLANT, DISTRIBUTION AND COLLECTION DEPARTMENT.
   The city operates a water plant, sewer plant, water distribution lines and
wastewater collection lines. It shall be the function of the water plant, sewer
plant, water distribution and wastewater collection department to ensure the
efficient operation of said facilities and to provide adequate water treatment,
sewage treatment, water distribution and wastewater collection for the city.
The department head shall oversee and direct all of the employees, that may be
assigned him or her by the city commission, toward obtaining said operation. He
or she shall prescribe regulations for the employees in the performance of
their duties. It shall be the function of the department head to secure
sufficient number of employees to perform an effective operation of the two (2)
plants. He or she shall have the right to hire and fire employees for any
reason contained in the personnel manual of the city, and shall notify the
mayor and/or the city commission of the various operations of the plants.
   The supervision and maintenance of the plant buildings shall likewise be a
function of the department. The department head shall be empowered to make
whatever repairs to said buildings as he or she may deem appropriate and
feasible.
(Ord. No. 064-1993, 12-14-93; Am. Ord. 029-2021, 1-11-21)
   Cross reference-Utilities generally,
Chapter 23.
§ 2-524. METER AND ELECTRIC DEPARTMENT.
   The function of the meter and electric department shall be to provide water
facilities and electrical service to all of the city customers. This shall
include but is not limited to the reading of meters and repairs and maintenance
of all electrical facilities and water meters. The department shall likewise be
responsible for the maintenance of any buildings used by the city in the
pursuit of the electric and water business, with joint supervision of the city
hall building. The city commission shall assign the necessary employees for the
performance of the department functions. The department head shall have the
right to hire additional employees or discharge employees upon failure to
perform their duties or any other reason set forth in the personnel manual of
the city. The department head shall have the right to promulgate procedures and
regulations for his or her respective employees. He or she shall report to the
board of commissioners and/or mayor upon request as to the activities and
general condition of his or her department. All bills received by the
department shall be approved prior to payment of the department head.
(Ord. No. 064-1993, 12-14-93; Am. Ord. 029-2021, 1-11-21)
§ 2-525. Streets and cemetery departments.
   The function of the streets and parks department shall be to provide
maintenance for the streets and parks, now or subsequently, dedicated to the
city for public use. The city commission shall assign the necessary employees
for the performance of the department functions. The department head shall have
the right to hire additional employees or discharge employees upon failure to
perform their duties or any other reasons set forth in the personnel manual of
the city. The department head shall have the right to promulgate procedures and
regulations for his or her respective employees. He or she shall report to the
board of commissioners and/or mayor upon request as to the activities and
general condition of his department. All bills received by the department shall
be approved prior to payment by the department head. The department head shall
likewise supervise the maintenance of all the park buildings and shall
prescribe rules and regulations for the use of the various city parks.
   The function of the cemetery department shall be to provide burial and
maintenance in the Maple Grove Cemetery. This shall include but is not limited
to working with funeral directors, the sale of cemetery lots and maintaining
detailed maps of burial lots. The department shall likewise be responsible for
the maintenance of the grounds and any buildings used by the city in the
pursuit of the cemetery department. The city commission shall assign the
necessary employees for the performance of the department functions. The
department head shall have the right to promulgate procedures and regulations
for his or her respective employees. He or she shall report to the board of
commissioners and/or mayor upon request as to the activities and general
condition of his or her department. The department head shall review all
expenditures and income that may come into the city treasury as a result of the
operation of the employees in his or her respective department. He or she shall
likewise approve all expenditures prior to payment by the treasurer. The policy
and procedures of the cemetery department may be reviewed and/or adjusted by
the board of commissioners and mayor as deemed necessary by resolution.
(Ord. No. 064-1993, 12-14-93; Am. Ord. 029-2021, 1-11-21)
§ 2-526. Administrative departments (including finance and planning and
zoning).
   The function of the finance and administrative department shall be to
generally oversee the finances of the city and all departments as well as to
coordinate all of the other four (4) departments described above. The
department shall likewise be in charge of and handle all of the billing and
collection of all of the utilities sold by the city as well as the
administration of the tax assessments. The function of the Planning and Zoning
Department is to assist the public, the Planning Commission and the Board of
Adjustments in coordinating and administrating a logical, methodical
development of the municipality in accordance with existing and future needs
and goals and to assist the Planning Commission and the city to engage in
planning operations as defined in KRS 100.111(14). The department head of this
department shall be the mayor of the city. He shall co-supervise the
maintenance of the city hall building. The city commission shall assign the
employees necessary for the operation of his department. He shall have the
right to hire additional employees or discharge employees upon failure to
perform their duties or any other reason set forth in the personnel manual of
the city. The mayor shall have the right to promulgate procedures and
regulations for his respective employees.
   The city treasurer, city clerk, city attorney and city administrative
officer shall be responsible to the mayor who in turn shall prescribe their
duties in addition to their existing functions and duties presently prescribed
by ordinance and statute.
(Ord. No. 064-1993, 12-14-93; Am. Ord. 1073-2019, 9-25-19; Am. Ord. 029-2021,
1-11- 21)

Chapter 2 .
