Chapter 15 POLICE*
Art. I.   In General, §§ 15-1--15-20
Art. II.   Police Department, §§ 15-21--15-33
   *Cross references-Disasters and emergencies,
Chapter 7; offenses,
Chapter 12; traffic and motor vehicles,
Chapter 22; authority of police officers to direct traffic, §
22-3.
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
§ 15-1. ARREST FEES TO BE PAID INTO CITY TREASURY.
   All arrest fees provided by Kentucky Revised Statutes and attributable to
arrests by city police officers are hereby directed to be paid into the city
treasury.
(Ord. No. 10-G-79, 10-23-79)
§ 15-2. USE OF DIALAMATIC AND AUDIBLE ALARM SYSTEMS.
   (a)   There is hereby prohibited in the city the use, by any person, the
dialamatic and audible alarm systems; however this prohibition does not affect
or relate to any residential use of an audible alarm system.
   (b)   An audible alarm system, for the purpose of this section, shall be
defined as any device designed for the detection of unauthorized entry on
premises and when actuated generates an audible sound on the premises.
   (c)   For the purpose of this section, a dialamatic alarm system, is one
that uses an automatic dial via the telephone to the police department.
(Ord. No. 017-1984, 6-12-84)
Secs. 15-3--15-20. RESERVED.
ARTICLE II. POLICE DEPARTMENT†
   †Cross references-Department generally, §
2-521 et seq.; police and fire departments, §
2-522.
§ 15-21. CREATED.
   There is hereby created a police department for the city.
(Code 1972, § 16-1)
§ 15-22. COMPOSITION.
   The police department shall consist of such officers and employees as the
city commission may from time to time provide.
(Code 1972, § 16-2)
§ 15-23. POSITION OF CHIEF OF POLICE CREATED.
   (a)   There is hereby created the non-elected office of chief of police,
which shall be filled by appointment of the city commission.
   (b)   The powers and duties of this office are hereby established as those
contained or set forth in the Kentucky Revised Statutes and those included in
the class specifications of the city's classification plan, and related duties
as requested or assigned.
   (c)   The oath of office to be executed by the police chief shall be that as
set forth in Sec. 228 of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Kentucky.
   (d) Compensation for this office shall be included in the city's
compensation plan.
   (e)   The Employment Policies and Procedures of the city shall apply to this
office.
(Code 1972, § 16-3; Ord. No. 473-2004, 1-29-04)
   State law reference–Nonelective city offices and officers, KRS 83A.
§ 15-24. COMMAND OF DEPARTMENT.
   The supervision of the police department shall be exercised by the chief of
police, subject to the overall command of the mayor.
(Code 1972, § 16-4)
§ 15-25. QUALIFICATIONS OF POLICE OFFICERS.
   Members of the police department shall have the qualifications required by
KRS 95.710.
(Code 1972, § 16-6)
§ 15-26. GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES OF POLICE OFFICERS.
   Members of the police department shall have the powers and duties prescribed
by law, and are hereby directed to enforce all ordinances and regulations of
the city and all laws of the state.
(Code 1972, § 16-7)
§ 15-27. RECORDS, REPORTS OF CHIEF OF POLICE.
   The chief of police shall keep an accurate record of all activities of or
matters affecting the police department, and shall report thereon to the city
commission monthly.
(Code 1972, § 16-8)
§ 15-28. CHIEF OF POLICE TO ATTEND, GIVE NOTICE OF CITY COMMISSION MEETINGS.
   It shall be the duty of the chief of police to attend all the meetings of
the city commission, and give notice of such meetings to the members of the
city commission, when directed so to do by the mayor or any two (2) members of
the city commission.
(Code 1972, § 16-10)
§ 15-29. UNIFORM REQUIRED.
   All police officers while on duty shall wear the uniform prescribed by the
city commission.
(Code 1972, § 16-11)
§ 15-30. TAKING CARS OUT OF CITY.
   It shall be unlawful to take any police department vehicle out of the city
except on official police business, unless permission is first obtained from
the chief of police.
(Code 1972, § 16-12)
§ 15-31. AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE.
   (a)   An auxiliary police force in the city is hereby created in accordance
with the provisions of KRS 95.445.
   (b)   The auxiliary police force shall consist of not less than one (1) nor
more than twelve (12) members who may be men or women.
   (c)   All members shall be responsible to the chief of police and shall
conform to rules and regulations as prescribed by the chief of police.
   (d)   Powers and duties of the auxiliary police force shall be to enforce
the laws of the Commonwealth of Kentucky and ordinances of the City of
Nicholasville. Auxiliary police officers shall have the power to issue
citations while on duty for violation of city ordinances and to motorists and/
or pedestrians for traffic violations; motorists shall abide by directions and
orders of the auxiliary police officers in operating their motor vehicles in
the city.
   (e)   Salaries for the auxiliary police force shall be set by the city
commission; however, the position may be held and performed voluntarily by any
respective member or members.
(Code 1972, § 16-13; Ord. No. 096-1986, 6-10-86)
§ 15-32. POLICE OFFICERS ALLOWED TO CARRY WEAPONS.
   It shall be lawful for police officers of the city to carry guns and
firearms on their person at all times, whether on duty or off duty.
(Code 1972, § 16-14)
§ 15-33. DISPATCHER'S OFFICE.
   A notice shall be posted in the dispatcher's office stating that only on-
duty law enforcement officers and elected city officials are permitted in the
dispatcher's office. The dispatchers shall enforce this order.
(Code 1972, § 16-15)
Chapter 16 PRECIOUS METALS DEALERS*
   *Cross reference-Sales,
Chapter 17.
§ 16-1. DEFINED.
   The term "precious metals dealer", for the purpose of this chapter, shall
mean any business, excluding banking institutions licensed to do business in
the state, making any secondhand purchase of gold, silver, platinum, copper, or
aluminum, whether in the form of bulk metal, coins, watches, jewelry or any
other form. The term secondhand purchase shall not include any purchase made by
a retailer or wholesaler from a bona fide manufacturer.
(Ord. No. 2-C-81, 3-10-81; Ord. No. 600-2006, 7-27-06; Ord. No. 640-2007, 2-22-
07)
   Cross reference-Definitions and rules of construction generally, §
1-2.
§ 16-2. RECORD KEEPING.
   (a)   Any business meeting the definition of precious metals dealers shall
keep a record of all purchases of gold, silver, platinum, copper, or aluminum.
The police department shall furnish one set of standard forms to a dealer for
such purposes, which shall at a minimum require the following information:
date; time; amount paid by the dealer for the item; manufacturer name and
pattern, if ascertainable; serial number, if any; any distinguishing marks or
engraving; weight of the item; pattern; number of items; and settings if any.
Additionally, the following information shall be required for the sellers:
name; address; date of birth; age; hair color; race; sex; height; weight;
build; general appearance; distinguishing marks; legible right thumb print;
driver's license number or numbers from one (1) means of identification, which
may include credit cards, and a photograph.
   (b)   All precious metals dealers shall furnish to the police department
each day by 11:00 a.m., a copy of the completed record form for all
transactions which took place during the preceding day. It shall be the duty of
any precious metals dealer to allow any member of the police department to
examine and inspect the records required above, and if sufficient information
cannot be gained from inspection of the records, it shall be the duty of any
precious metals dealer to permit and allow the officer to examine any and all
such articles still in their possession.
   (c)   Each and every article or set of articles received by a precious
metals dealer shall be kept with the aforementioned record form attached,
during the entire time it is in the possession of the licensee or until the
item is altered or changed in such a way as to make it no longer readily
identifiable, whichever happens first. All such articles shall be retained at
the place of business or other location where the articles may be readily
available, upon request, to the police department in the same state or
condition in which they were received, for a period of six (6) consecutive days
after their receipt, during which time they shall not be resold, exchanged or
otherwise disposed of. Coins having no numismatic value, Krugerrands and
manufactured ingots, shall be so retained for five (5) consecutive days.
   (d)   Any adult or minor selling aluminum cans will not be required to
complete the precious metals form, therefore the precious metals dealer will
not be required to hold aluminum cans for any length of time.
(Ord. No. 2-C-81, 3-10-81; Ord. No. 600-2006, 7-27-06; Ord. No. 640-2007, 2-22-
07)
§ 16-3. PROHIBITED PURCHASES.
   In no case shall a precious metals dealer make a secondhand purchase of
gold, silver, platinum, copper, or aluminum, from a minor. Such purchases shall
likewise not be made of any goods which the precious metals dealer knows or has
reason to believe are stolen.
(Ord. No. 2-C-81, 3-10-81; Ord. No. 600-2006, 7-27-06; Ord. No. 640-2007, 2-22-
07)
Chapter 17 SALES*
Art. I.   In General, §§ 17-1–17-15
Art. II.   Yard Sales, §§ 17-16–17-19
Art. III.    Automobile Sales, §§ 17-20–17-23
Art. IV. Itinerant Merchants, §§ 17-24–17-33
   *Cross reference-Precious metals dealers,
Chapter 16.
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Secs. 17-1--17-15. RESERVED.
ARTICLE II. YARD SALES
§ 17-16. DEFINED.
   The term "yard sales", for the purposes of this article, shall constitute
the sale of furniture, household equipment and other related items by a person
not already engaged in a lawful licensed business for the particular site of
the sale in the city.
(Code 1972, § 13-12(a))
   Cross reference-Definitions and rules of construction generally, §
1-2
§ 17-17. PERMIT.
   (a)   The chief of police is hereby empowered to issue a permit upon request
for yard sales to any resident of the city, provided no person shall be issued
more than two (2) permits during the calendar year, nor shall there be a permit
issued for one (1) site more than twice a year during the calendar year.
   (b)   There shall be a fee of five dollars ($5.00) for the issuance of a
permit under this section
(Code 1972, § 13-12(b), (d); Ord. No. 540-2005, 8-11-05)
§ 17-18. DURATION.
   The duration of a yard sale shall run no longer than two (2) consecutive
days, excluding Sundays.
(Code 1972, § 13-12(c))
§ 17-19. VIOLATIONS.
   Failure on the part of the owner, occupant or any person conducting a yard
sale to obtain a permit therefor, shall constitute a misdemeanor.
(Code 1972, § 13-12(e))
ARTICLE III. AUTOMOBILE SALES
§ 17-20. DEFINED.
   As used in this section "automobile dealer" means any person, partnership,
corporation, or other legal entity engaged in selling, offering to sell,
trading, soliciting, or advertising the sale of new or used motor vehicles, or
possessing motor vehicles for the purposes of resale, or trade either on his
own account, or on behalf of another, either as his primary business or
incidental thereto. "Automobile dealer" shall not mean any private citizen or
person not engaged in the business of selling, offering to sell, soliciting, or
advertising the sale of new or used motor vehicles privately unless that person
is selling vehicles as a business interest, nor shall this article apply to
banks, lending institutions, or financial institutions conducting a private or
public sale of repossessed motor vehicles or motor vehicles sold under court
order or through foreclosure proceedings.
(Ord. No. 423-2002, 9-19-02)
§ 17-21. PLACE OF BUSINESS.
   (a)   Every automobile dealer desiring to sell or trade or conduct a sale of
new or used automobiles within the city limits must maintain an established
place of business within the city which is easily accessible and open for
business at all reasonable hours. An established place of business must include
both an office and a vehicle storage/display lot, at a location that is
properly zoned for such use, and must include its own mailing address.
   (b)   The sale, transfer, display, or trading of vehicles shall only be
allowed on a location within the city limits. All improvements shall be
completed in accordance with development plans submitted and approved by the
planning commission.
   (c)   The place of business from which the sale of automobiles is to be
conducted within the city must have an office in a permanent, enclosed,
commercial (not residential) structure on, or adjoining, the storage/display
lot. The office must have at least one hundred (100) square feet of floor
space, electricity, and a business telephone. The office must be set up in such
a way that it is not used for any other purpose other than the sale of
vehicles.
   (d)   The vehicle storage/display lot must have at least two thousand
(2,000) square feet, and have an impermeable dust free surface covering
consisting of either asphalt or concrete and must be set up in such a manner
that it may not be used for any other purpose other than display or storage of
vehicles for sale, or dealer customer parking. All storage/display lots must
comply with city zoning regulations, as established. All vehicles shall be
stored and/or displayed on private property. No vehicles shall be stored and/or
displayed on public right-of-way. All construction and development of the
automobile sales land must comply with city zoning regulations.
   (e)   Every automobile dealer must have a sign, which identifies the dealer
business by name, which is placed on the premises so that it is clearly visible
and can easily be read from the nearest roadway, with lettering of at least
nine (9) inches in height. All other sign provisions of the city zoning
ordinance must be followed.
(Ord. No. 423-2002, 9-19-02)
§ 17-22. LICENSE CERTIFICATE REQUIRED.
   Any automobile dealer conducting business within the City limits must have a
valid license certificate as required by KRS Ch. 190 et seq. and the
regulations of the Kentucky Motor Vehicle Commission. The dealer license
certificate and one copy of all sales persons' licenses must be conspicuously
displayed in the automobile dealer's office as well as a city business license.
(Ord. No. 423-2002, 9-19-02)
§ 17-23. BUSINESS LICENSE REQUIRED.
   Prior to the conduction of any business by an automobile dealer within the
city, the dealer shall apply for all business licenses and pay the license fees
required under the city Fee Ordinance and amendments thereof.
(Ord. No. 423-2002, 9-19-02)
ARTICLE IV. ITINERANT MERCHANTS
Sec. 17-24.   Definitions.
   (a)   Door to door sales. Going from dwelling unit to dwelling unit (i.e.
house, apartment, condominium, etc.) or from business to business in Jessamine
County selling or taking orders for, or offering to sell or take orders for,
goods, wares and merchandise for present or future delivery or for services to
be performed immediately or in the future whether such person has, carries or
exposes a sample of such goods, wares and merchandise or not and whether he/she
is collecting advance payments on such sales or not.
   (b)   Downtown. The area which is bounded to the northeast by Richmond
Avenue, and to the northwest by North Third Street, to the southeast by East
Brown Street and the southwest by West Brown Street, which shall include both
sides of the above enumerated boundary streets and any sidewalks located within
those boundaries.
   (c)   Itinerant merchant. An individual or entity that engages in the
selling, vending, supplying or providing of agricultural products such as fresh
produce, seasonal fruits, fresh plants or flowers, value-added products, arts
and crafts items, food, beverages, or any other merchandise from a temporary
stand, tent, vehicle, truck, trailer, cart, wagon, motorized or human-powered
wheeled device, or any other non-permanent structure within the City of
Nicholasville, Kentucky. Itinerant merchant shall expressly include an
individual or entity that conducts business from a mobile food truck (whether
independently motorized, a vehicle-towed trailer, or otherwise mobile) in which
food is cooked and/or prepared to order and is served to walk up customers.
This definition shall not include an individual or entity that is associated
with a restaurant that operates from a fixed location, provided that said
restaurant otherwise falls outside the scope of the definition of "itinerant
merchant" and all food sales from such units shall be reported with the overall
sales of the restaurant and pay all applicable taxes as required by KRS
91A.400.
   (d)   Special event. Any activity, festival, event or other community
gathering recognized by resolution of the city commission of the City of
Nicholasville as a special event.
   (e)   Transient merchant. Shall have the same meaning as set forth in KRS
365.650.
(Ord. No. 015-2020, 9-28-20)
Sec. 17-25.   Licensing requirements.
   (a)   All itinerant merchants shall be required to secure an occupational
license and otherwise comply with
Chapter 27 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Nicholasville, Kentucky. As a
part of the application process, the applicant must specify a permanent
business address where any and all notices shall be mailed. Itinerant merchants
are required to notify the occupational tax office of any changes in their
permanent business address in accordance with
Chapter 27 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Nicholasville, Kentucky.
   (b)   All itinerant merchants shall be required to secure a valid permit
from the Nicholasville Planning Commission in accordance with the Nicholasville
zoning ordinance. The application shall also include a copy of the occupational
license and documentation showing that the merchant has been inspected by the
City of Nicholasville Fire Marshal, meeting NFPA 1-50.7, and all applicable
codes and referenced standards at the time the permit is issued, and by the
Jessamine County Health Department, if applicable. The application shall also
include the mobile food unit license number, description, VIN and proof of
automotive insurance. Upon approval of an application, the Nicholasville
Planning Commission shall issue a permit specifying the name of the itinerant
merchant and the exact location at which he is certified to do business. The
permit shall not be transferable. Said permit shall be posted in a prominent
place at that location at all times. If an itinerant merchant desires to change
location at which he is licensed to do business, the merchant must notify the
Fire Marshal by email or other written notice. All itinerant merchants shall
renew their certificate of occupancy on an annual basis in accordance with the
Nicholasville zoning ordinance. All permits will expire on February 28th of
each permit cycle year.
   (c)   It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally provide false
information or to intentionally omit requested information on an application
for any license, certificate or permit pertaining to itinerant merchants.
   (d)   As a condition of issuance of an occupational license and a permit,
the itinerant merchant agrees to indemnify, hold harmless, and defend the City
of Nicholasville and its officials, officers, employees, representatives and
agents against liability and/or loss arising from activities connection with
and/or undertaken pursuant to the license or permit. The City of Nicholasville
is not liable for any business loss, property loss, or other damage that may
result from the use of the license or permit, or suspension or revocation of
the license or permit, and no such merchant shall maintain any claim or action
against the City of Nicholasville and/or its officials, officers, employees, or
agents on account of any suspension or revocation. Said license and permit may
be revoked by the City of Nicholasville for failure to comply with this Article
or for other violation of law.
   (e)   Itinerant merchants shall pay an annual permit fee of one hundred
sixty dollars ($160.00) and shall be inspected no less than once per year by
the City of Nicholasville Fire Marshal.
(Ord. No. 015-2020, 9-28-20)
Sec. 17-26.   Regulation of itinerant merchants.
   All itinerant merchants must comply with the following:
   (a)   Shall be subject to all applicable ordinances and regulations unless
expressly provided otherwise herein. These include, but are not limited to,
those matters pertaining to zoning, public safety, pedestrian and state traffic
laws, restricted sales or vending areas, parking and licensing.
   (b)   Must obtain all necessary licenses and permissions and comply with all
requirements imposed by the Kentucky Department of Public Health, the State of
Kentucky Food Safety Branch, and other regulatory agencies.
   (c)   Shall at all times operate in a manner that ensures the safety of
patrons, pedestrians and the public.
   (d)   Ensure that any vehicle, other conveyance, structure, or stand used in
the operation of the business is maintained and kept in good operating order.
   (e)   Shall remain at one address for no more than two (2) consecutive weeks
and, after such time, must vacate that address for a minimum of thirty (30)
days.
   (f)   Merchants with any type of cooking equipment (e.g. fryers, grills,
etc.) shall be inspected by the City Fire Marshal. The Fire Marshal inspections
shall be done by appointment only with a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) inspection
fee.
   (g)   Shall provide and use tarp, roofing paper, or similar impermeable
material or protective barrier under and around the structure from which the
itinerant merchant conducts business in order to prevent spilling, staining or
contamination onto or into any public property.
   (h)   Shall provide, in a prominent location, trash and/or recycling
containers sufficient in size to collect all waste and recyclables generated by
customers and staff of the itinerant merchant. All trash and debris related to
the operation shall be collected by the itinerant merchant throughout the
duration of their operation and deposited in their own trash or recycling
containers and removed from the site by the itinerant merchant. Such waste
shall not be placed in any City of Nicholasville trash receptacles. The
itinerant merchant shall be responsible for any litter or debris located within
a five (5) feet radius of their operation, including sidewalks in the immediate
vicinity.
   (i)   Ensure that its operations do not violate or contribute to a violation
of any noise ordinance adopted by the City of Nicholasville.
   (j)   Ensure that any and all signs are compliant with any ordinances or
regulations retaining to signage and located only within the area lawfully
permitted for conducting of business.
   (k)   Shall only use lighting which is permanently or semi-permanently
affixed to its unit and which does not cause any glare that could be considered
a public health hazard, nuisances or distraction to vehicular movement,
neighboring business operations and/or residential uses. No flashing or strobe
lighting shall be permitted.
   (l)   Shall not use any electrical outlet located within the public right-
of-way or on public property unless specifically authorized by the City of
Nicholasville and, if required, the utility company. An itinerant merchant
shall not create any tripping or other hazard related to its use of
electricity.
   (m)   Shall not block access to or use of any public bench or any public
utility pole or set up any chairs or tables on the public right-of-way.
   (n)   Shall not park or operate in a manner that prohibits or unreasonably
interferes with parking in otherwise available spaces or areas.
   (o)   Shall not in any manner damage public property or the public right-of-
way. Examples include, but are not limited to, using stakes, rods, or any
method of support that is required to be drilled, driven or otherwise fixed in
asphalt pavement, curbs, sidewalks or buildings. The itinerant merchant shall
be solely responsible for any such damage.
   (p)   No sales or service of alcohol shall be allowed by itinerant
merchants.
(Ord. No. 015-2020, 9-28-20)
Sec. 17-27.   Hours of operation.
   Unless otherwise authorized by the City of Nicholasville, the general lawful
hours of operation shall be limited to the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m.
However, the hours of operation shall be allowed to continue after 11:00 p.m.
if a permanent business also located on that parcel of property is open to the
general public. In those instances, the itinerant merchant may lawfully
continue to conduct business until the time at which such a permanent business
is closed to the general public.
(Ord. No. 015-2020, 9-28-20)
Sec. 17-28.   Locations.
   Unless otherwise permitted or authorized by the City of Nicholasville, no
itinerant merchant shall locate or conduct business in the following manner or
within the following specified areas of locations:
   (a)   Within fifteen (15) feet of any driveway or other main entrance to a
building without the express written permission of the affected property owner
or his or her authorized agent.
   (b)   Within five hundred (500) feet of a special event without the express
written permission of the special event coordinator.
   (c)   Within an area closed for an emergency.
   (d)   On public property, including but not limited to the public right-of-
way, unless the itinerant merchant has obtained any additional appropriate
licensure and such property has been designated for such use by the City of
Nicholasville through a resolution, ordinance, or the adoption of a pilot
program, or the City of Nicholasville has otherwise provided express permission
for such conduct.
(Ord. No. 015-2020, 9-28-20)
Sec. 17-29.   Liability of property owner.
   No property owner shall allow an itinerant merchant to conduct business on
such owner's property in violation of this Article IV.
(Ord. No. 015-2020, 9-28-20)
Sec. 17-30.   Approval by Planning and Zoning.
   (a)   The proposed location(s) of the itinerant merchant shall be set forth
in the application to Planning and Zoning. The application to Planning and
Zoning shall contain information as reasonably required by that division and
shall, at a minimum, include a site plan clearly depicting the proposed
location(s) for the itinerant merchant.
   (b)   The Division of Planning and Zoning shall review the application for
the permit and shall be authorized to approve it upon finding the following:
      (1)   Minimum off-street parking spaces as required for the site shall be
maintained; however, no new parking spaces shall be required for a mobile food
vendor;
      (2)   The location specified for itinerant merchants allows for proper
vehicular and pedestrian access and circulation on the site, including fire
access;
      (3)   That the site is zoned in a category that permits restaurants as a
principal permitted use, or that site restrictions are in a place that make the
itinerant merchant's business compliant with applicable zoning restrictions
related to the serving of food within the zone; as part of this consideration,
Planning and Zoning shall consider that "downtown" is deemed a favorable area
in general terms, in the interest of promoting economic development;
      (4)   Approval by the City Fire Marshal.
(Ord. No. 015-2020, 9-28-20)
Sec. 17-31.   Exceptions.
   No permit shall be required for the following:
   (a)   Yard sales, garage sales, bake sales or other similar types of
activities. These activities must be temporary and non-recurring in nature and
must comply with all local ordinance and zoning ordinance provisions and must
not be located on public property or public right-of-way unless expressly
authorized by the City of Nicholasville;
   (b)   Vending activities by otherwise appropriately licensed and permitted
merchants at a special event;
   (c)   Newspaper carriers or newspaper vendors; to merchants or their
employees in delivering goods in the regular course of business; or to vendors'
products distributed or sold to regular customers on established routes;
   (d)   Delivery of goods pursuant to an agreement reached prior to the
vendor's arrival, provided that the vendor is otherwise properly licensed;
   (e)   Vending activities solely for the benefit of a bona fide, properly
licensed, nonprofit organization; and
   (f)   Vending activities solely for private catering purposes and when all
of the following provision are met:
      (1)   The itinerant merchant is located entirely on private property; and
      (2)   Service is limited to the guests of catered event only.
(Ord. No. 015-2020, 9-28-20)
Sec. 17-32.   Penalty.
   (a)   Each violation of this Article IV is hereby classified as a civil
offense and shall be subject to the following schedule or civil fines:
      (1)   If a citation for a violation of this Article IV is not contested
by the person charged with the violation, the following fines shall apply:
 
1st Offense 2nd Offense All Others
$50.00      $100.00     $150.00
 
      (2)   If a citation is contested and a hearing before the Code
Enforcement Board is required, the following maximum penalties may be imposed
at the discretion of the Code Enforcement Board:
 
1st Offense 2nd Offense All Others
$100.00     $200.00     $300.00
 
   (b)   The Code Enforcement Board shall have the power to issue remedial
orders and impose civil fines as method of enforcing this Article IV in
accordance with Sec. 11-4 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Nicholasville,
Kentucky.
   (c)   Each day a violation occurs constitutes a separate offense.
(Ord. No. 015-2020, 9-28-20)
Sec. 17-33.   Transient merchants.
   (a)   A transient merchant must have filed a completed transient merchant
application with the division of revenue at least ten (10) days prior to
conducting business, as required by KRS 365.655.
   (b)   Door to door sales are prohibited before 9:00 a.m. or after 8:00 p.m.,
or any time on Sunday or on a state or national holiday.
   (c)   A transient merchant must be eighteen (18) years or older, or, if
between the ages of fourteen (14) and seventeen (17), inclusive, must submit
proof of a valid work permit.
   (d)   Transient merchants shall conduct himself/herself at all times in an
orderly and lawful manner.
   (e)   No transient merchant shall enter a home, residence, apartment complex
or business under pretenses other than those directly connected with his or her
business as a transient merchant.
   (f)   No transient merchant shall engage or attempt to engage in his or her
business as a transient merchant at any home, residence, apartment complex or
business that prominently displays "no peddlers", "no solicitors" or "no
trespassing" signs or any other similar sign that communicates the occupants'
desire to not be contacted by transient merchants.
   (g)   No transient merchant shall remain in a home, residence, apartment
complex or business or on the premises thereof after the owner or occupant has
requested that the transient merchant leave.
   (h)   All orders taken by a transient merchant shall be in writing in
duplicate stating the name as it appears on the license and address of both the
transient merchant and his or her employer, if any, the terms of the order, the
amount paid in advance, and one (1) copy shall be given to the purchaser.
(Ord. No. 015-2020, 9-28-20)
Chapter 18 SOLID WASTE*
   *Cross references-Housing,
Chapter 10, nuisances,
Chapter 11; occupational license tax on garbage collection and disposal, § 21-
33(51); utilities,
Chapter 23.
§ 18-1. DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter the following terms shall be deemed to have
the meaning indicated below:
      Bulky rubbish. Nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of combustible and/
or noncombustible waste materials from dwelling units, or commercial,
industrial, institutional or agricultural establishments, which are either too
large or too heavy to be safely and conveniently loaded in solid waste
collection vehicles by solid waste collectors, with the equipment available
therefor.
      Collection. Removal and transportation of solid waste from its place of
storage to its place of processing or disposal.
      Construction and demolition waste. Materials such as lumber, bricks,
dirt, stone, plaster, roofing, sheathing, rubble, conduit pipe, wire insulation
and other similar items resulting from repairs, additions, destruction or
construction of buildings.
      Disposable solid waste container. Disposable plastic or paper sacks with
a capacity of ten (10) to thirty-five (35) gallons specifically designed for
storage of solid waste.
      Dwelling unit. Any room or group of rooms located within a structure, and
forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are used, or are intended
to be used, for living, sleeping, cooking and eating.
      Garbage. Putrescible animal or vegetable wastes resulting from the
handling, preparation, cooking, serving or consumption of food.
      Hazardous wastes. Includes but is not limited to pathological wastes,
explosive wastes, pesticides, pesticide containers, toxic or radioactive
materials.
      Multiple housing facility. A housing facility containing more than one
(1) dwelling unit under one (1) roof.
      Occupant. Any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others,
shall be in actual possession of any dwelling unit or of any other improved
real property, either as owner or as a tenant.
      Owner.  Any person or other legal entities, including but not limited to
a partnership, corporation, limited liability company, or trust, having an
interest in real estate.
      Person. Any individual, partnership, firm, company, corporation,
association, joint stock company, trust estate, political subdivision, or
organization of any kind, or their legal representative, agent or assigns.
      Processing. Incinerating, composting, baling, shredding, salvaging,
compacting and other processes whereby solid waste characteristics are modified
or solid waste quantity is reduced.
      Refuse. Solid waste.
      Solid waste. Unwanted or discarded waste materials in a solid or semi-
solid state, including but not limited to garbage, ashes, street refuse,
rubbish, dead animals, animal and agricultural wastes, yard wastes, discarded
appliances, special wastes, industrial wastes, and demolition and construction
wastes.
         (1)   Commercial solid waste. Solid waste resulting from the operation
of any commercial, industrial, institutional or agricultural establishment, and
multiple housing facilities with more than four (4) dwelling units.
         (2)   Residential solid waste. Solid waste resulting from the
maintenance and operation of dwelling units, excluding multiple housing
facilities with more than four (4) dwelling units.
      Solid waste container. A receptacle used by any person to store solid
waste during the interval between solid waste collection.
      Solid waste disposal. The process of discarding or getting rid of
unwanted material, in particular the final deposition of solid waste by man.
      Solid waste management. The entire solid waste system of storage,
collection, transportation, processing and disposal.
      Storage. Keeping, maintaining or storing solid waste from the time of its
production until the time of its collection.
      Yard wastes. Grass clippings, leaves and tree trimmings.
(Ord. No. 2-F-79, § 1, 2-27-79; Ord. No. 662-2007, 9-7-07; Ord. No. 699-2008,
5-15-08)
   Cross reference-Definitions and rules of construction generally, §
1-2
§ 18-2. STORAGE.
   (a)   The owner of every dwelling unit and every institutional, commercial
or business, industrial or agricultural establishment producing solid waste
with the city shall provide sufficient and adequate containers for the storage
of all solid waste except bulky rubbish and demolition and construction waste
to serve each such dwelling unit and/or establishment; and to maintain such
solid waste containers at all times in good repair.
   (b)   The owner of every dwelling unit and of every institutional,
commercial, industrial, agricultural or business establishment shall place all
solid waste to be collected in proper solid waste containers, except as
otherwise provided herein, and shall maintain such solid waste containers and
the area surrounding them in a clean, net and sanitary condition at all times.
   (c)   Residential solid waste shall be stored in containers of not more than
thirty-five (35) gallons nor less than ten (10) gallons in nominal capacity.
Containers shall be leakproof, waterproof, and fitted with a fly-tight lid and
shall be properly covered at all times except when depositing waste therein or
removing the contents thereof. The containers shall have handles, bails or
other suitable lifting devices or features. Containers shall be of a type
originally manufactured for residential solid waste, with tapered sides for
easy emptying. They shall be of light weight and sturdy construction. The
weight of any individual container and contents shall not exceed seventy-five
(75) pounds. Galvanized metal containers, rubber or fiberglass containers, and
plastic containers which do not become brittle in cold weather, may be used.
Disposable solid waste containers with suitable frames or containers as
approved by the city may also be used for storage of residential solid waste.
   (d)   Commercial solid waste shall be stored in solid waste containers as
approved by the city. The containers shall be waterproof, leakproof and shall
be covered at all times except when depositing waste therein or removing the
contents thereof; and shall meet all requirements as set forth by §
18-5.
   (e)   Tree limbs less than four (4) inches in diameter and brush shall be
securely tied in bundles not larger than forty-eight (48) inches long and
eighteen (18) inches in diameter when not placed in store containers. The
weight of any individual bundle shall not exceed seventy-five (75) pounds.
   (f)   Yard wastes shall be stored in containers so constructed and
maintained as to prevent the dispersal of wastes placed therein upon the
premises served, upon adjacent premises, or upon adjacent public rights-of-way.
The weight of any individual container and contents shall not exceed seventy-
five (75) pounds.
   (g)   Solid waste containers which are not approved will be collected and
disposed of together with their contents.
(Ord. No. 2-F-79, § 2, 2-27-79; Ord. No. 662-2007, 9-7-07; Ord. No. 699-2008,
5-15-08)
§ 18-3. COLLECTION.
   (a)   The city shall provide for the collection of solid waste in the city
as described in this chapter. The owner of every residential property in the
city limits shall be responsible for garbage service at that property.
   (b)   Tree limbs and yard wastes, as described in §
18-2(e) and (f) respectively, shall be placed at the curbside for collection.
Solid waste containers as required by this chapter for the storage of other
residential solid waste shall be placed at the roadside for collection. Any
solid waste containers, tree limbs, yard wastes, or other solid waste permitted
by this chapter to be placed at the roadside for collection shall not be so
placed until the regularly scheduled collection day.
   (C)   The following collection frequencies shall apply to collections of
solid waste within the city: All residential solid waste, other than bulky
rubbish, shall be collected at least once weekly. All commercial solid waste
shall be collected at intervals necessary for the preservation of the health
and safety of the public.
   (D)   Residential solid waste containers shall be stored upon the
residential premises. Commercial solid waste containers shall be stored upon
private property, unless the owner shall have been granted written permission
from the appropriate agency to use public property for such purposes. The
storage site shall be well drained; fully accessible to collection equipment,
public healthy personnel and fire inspection personnel.
   (E)   All collection vehicles shall be maintained and operated so as to
prevent spillage of solid waste therefrom.
(Ord. No. 2-F-79, § 3, 2-27-79; Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 18-4. DISPOSAL.
   (A)   Solid waste shall be dispose of at a processing facility or disposal
area operated under the approval of the state,
   (B)   The city may classify certain wastes as hazardous wastes which will
require special handling and shall be disposed of only in a manner acceptable
to the city and which will meet all local, state and federal regulations.
(Ord. No. 2-F-79, § 4, 2-27-79; Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 18-5. RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The city shall make, amend, revoke and enforce reasonable and necessary
rules and regulations, governing, but not limited to:
      (1)   Preparation, drainage and wrapping of garbage deposited in solid
waste containers;
      (2)   Specifications for solid waste containers, including the type,
composition, equipment, size and shape thereof;
      (3)   Identification of solid waste containers and of the covers thereof,
and of equipment thereto appertaining, if any;
      (4)   Weight limitations on the combined weight of solid waste containers
and the contents thereof, and weight and size limitations on bundles of solid
waste too large for solid waste containers;
      (5)   Storage of solid waste in solid waste containers;
      (6)   Sanitation, maintenance and replacement of solid waste containers;
      (7)   Schedule of and routes for collection of solid waste;
      (8)   Collection points of solid waste containers;
      (9)   Collection and disposal of solid waste;
      (10)   Fees for the collection and disposal of solid waste;
      (11)   Handling of special wastes, such as toxic wastes, sludges, ashes,
agriculture, construction, bulky items, tires, automobiles, oils, greases,
etc.; and
      (12)   Containers
         a.   Roll cart containers and other receptacles for solid waste
including trash, garbage, and debris shall be placed at the curb no sooner than
7:00 p.m. on the evening prior to collection day and no later than 7:00 a.m. on
the day of collection.
         b.   Roll cart containers and receptacles shall be removed from the
curb no later than 7:00 p.m. on the day of collection.
         c.   Roll carts and other receptacles may be kept in the rear yard or
other enclosed facility when not at the curb for collection. Persons who do not
have rear yard access may be exempt from this provision upon approval of an
alternative storage location by the Environmental Enforcement Section Director.
         d.   Any violation of this ordinance shall be subject to a fine
pursuant to the provisions of Section
1-10 of the Code of Ordinances.
(Ord. No. 2-F-79, § 6, 2-27-79; Ord. No. 390-2001, 10-11-01; Ord. No. 699-2008,
5-15-08)
Sec. 18-6. PROHIBITED PRACTICES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to:
      (1)   Deposit solid waste in any solid waste container other than his own
with the intent of avoiding payment of the service charge hereinafter provided
for solid waste collection and disposal;
      (2)   Interfere in any manner with solid waste collection equipment, or
with solid waste collectors in the lawful performance of their duties as such;
      (3)   Burn solid waste unless an approved incinerator is provided or
unless a variance has been obtained from the appropriate air pollution control
agency;
      (4)   Dispose of solid waste at any facility or location which is not
approved.
(Ord. No. 2-F-79, § 7, 2-27-79; Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 18-7. SERVICE CHARGES.
   There is hereby imposed, for the collection and disposal of solid waste, a
service charge for each dwelling unit and each commercial establishment to
which such service shall be provided under the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. No. 2-F-79, § 8, 2-27-79; Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Chapter 19 STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES*
Art. I    In General, §§ 19-1--19-25
Art. II.   Street Lighting, §§ 19-26--19-34
Art. III.    Pedestrian, Safety; Pedestrians Approaching Vehicles or Being Upon
Median, Prohibited, §§ 19-40--19-44
 
   *Cross references-Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating,
relocating, opening, closing, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or
public way in the city saved from repeal, § 1-5(6); any ordinance establishing
and prescribing the street grades of any street in the city saved from repeal,
§ 1-5(7); water line, streets, and parks department, § 2-525; buildings and
building regulations, Chapter 6; parks and recreation, Chapter 13; planning,
Chapter 14; subdivisions, Chapter 20; traffic and motor vehicles, Chapter 22;
utilities, Chapter 23; zoning, Chapter 25.
   State law reference-Municipal improvements, KRS Chapter 107.
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
§ 19-1. ADOPTION OF GENERAL SPECIFICATIONS FOR THE CONSTRUCTION OF WATER
FACILITIES, SEWERAGE FACILITIES, STREETS AND STORM DRAINAGE FACILITIES.
   There is hereby adopted by reference, as if copied in full herein, the
General Specifications for the Construction of Water Facilities, Sewerage
Facilities, Streets and Storm Drainage. The ordinance has been filed with the
planning and zoning office and may be found there.
(Ord. No. 7-D-80, 7-1-80; Ord. No. 032-1991, 10-22-91)
§ 19-2. CITY STREETS IN STATE OR FEDERAL SYSTEM.
   (a)   Public hearing required. Before the city expends state derived tax
revenues on a municipal highway, road, street or bridge, it shall hold a
hearing in accordance with the provisions of this section to take the sense of
the public with regard to the project and to priorities for use of tax moneys
for road and bridge purposes.
   (b)   Notice requirements. Before the contemplated date of expenditure of
state derived tax revenues on a road or bridge by the city, the city shall give
notice in the manner required by KRS Chapter 424 of a public hearing to take
the sense of the public with regard to road and bridge matters within the city.
The hearing shall be held not less than seven (7) nor more than twenty-one (21)
days after the first publication of the notice and before beginning work on any
project covered by this section.
   State law reference-public hearing KRS 174.100, notice requirement KRS
174.100(1).
§ 19-3. PERMIT FOR WORK AFFECTING STREET.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to move, remove or disturb any dirt,
gravel, rock or other substance or material from any public street, alley, road
or thoroughfare within the city unless such person has first obtained from the
city administrator a specific written permit authorizing such activity.
(Code 1972, § 17-5)
§ 19-4. OBSTRUCTIONS AND ENCROACHMENTS.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, maintain or continue any
wall, fence, retaining wall or other obstruction or encroachment on or in any
of the public streets, highways, alleys or public ways within the city, which
interferes in any way with the free and unlimited use of the same by
pedestrians and vehicles, unless any expressed permit for such erection,
maintenance or continuance is obtained from the city commission.
   (b)   Upon complaint being made to the city commission by any person, the
mayor shall be directed to notify the person erecting, maintaining or
continuing such wall, fence, retaining wall, obstruction or encroachment to
appear before the commission at a stated time and date within thirty (30) days
and show cause why such obstruction or encroachment should not be removed. If,
at such hearing, the commission determines that such an obstruction or
encroachment does exist, the removal of such obstruction or encroachment within
thirty (30) days shall be ordered by the commission, and the person erecting,
maintaining or continuing such obstruction or encroachment shall be given
written notice of such order forthwith by registered mail with return receipt.
If such obstruction or encroachment is not removed within thirty (30) days from
the date of entry of such order on the minute book of the commission, the
person erecting, maintaining or continuing such obstruction or encroachment
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
   (c)   This section is in addition to, and not in lieu of, all other lawful
remedies available to the city or any citizen or resident thereof for the
abatement of nuisances or removal of obstructions or encroachments from public
streets, alleys and public ways.
(Code 1972, § 17-6)
§ 19-5. CLOSING OF STREET; USE WHEN CLOSED.
   (a)   The mayor is hereby authorized to temporarily close any street in the
city when the same is being reconstructed, repaired, or the surface treated, or
when otherwise necessary.
   (b)   When any street has been closed by order of the mayor, it shall be
unlawful for any person to make any use of the street, or to operate any
vehicle of any kind on the street.
(Code 1972, § 17-7)
§ 19-6. OWNERS TO CONSTRUCT, REPAIR SIDEWALKS, CURBS AND GUTTERS, REQUIRED FOR
NEW CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)   All owners of lots or parts of lots in the city that front on streets
or alleys shall cause sidewalks, curbs and gutters to be constructed in front
of their lots or parts of lots, the sidewalks, curbs and gutters to be made
such width and of such material and in such manner as the city commission may
deem expedient, and the owner or owners of such lots or parts of lots shall
cause sidewalks, curbs and gutters fronting their lots to be made or repaired
in such manner as the city commission may direct. If any owner or owners of
lots or parts of lots shall fail or refuse to cause the sidewalks, curbs and
gutters to be made or repaired as ordered by the city commission for a period
of thirty (30) days after the service of such order upon the owner or owners,
they shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. The Board of Commissioners may waive the
aforesaid requirements when in its’ opinion it is impractical and serves no
useful purpose to require sidewalks, curbs and gutters.
   (b)   A certificate of occupancy shall not be issued for a newly constructed
principal structure built on any lot until a sidewalk, curb and gutter have
been constructed in accordance with all applicable city standards and
specifications unless a variance waiving the herein stated requirements has
been granted by the planning commission for a subdivision plat and/or lot at
the time of approval of said plat and/or lot.
(Code 1972, § 17-9; Ord. No. 023-1993, 3-23-93; Am. No. 817-2011, 10-24-11)
§ 19-7. PROPERTY OWNERS TO CLEAN ABUTTING SIDEWALKS.
   All persons owning real estate in the city are hereby required to keep all
sidewalks abutting the property free from grass, weeds and obstructions of all
kinds.
(Code 1972, § 17-10)
§ 19-8. NOTICE REQUIRING SIDEWALK CLEANING.
   It shall be the duty of any police officer, whenever he has knowledge or
receives information that any property owner's sidewalk has become grown up
with grass or weeds, or is in untidy condition from any kind of obstruction or
filth, to notify such owner of the condition of his sidewalk, and order him to
forthwith have such grass, weeds, obstructions or filth removed, and the
sidewalk placed in a tidy condition; and should the owner fail for the space of
five (5) days to comply with the order, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(Code 1972, § 17-11)
§ 19-9. DUTY TO REMOVE SNOW AND ICE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person owning or occupying property in the city
to allow snow or ice to remain on their sidewalk for a longer period than
twenty-four (24) hours from the time the snow shall fall or the ice becomes
frozen.
(Code 1972, § 17-12)
§ 19-10. SIGNS PROHIBITED ON PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY AND PUBLIC PROPERTY; PENALTY.
   (a)   No sign shall be placed in any public rights-of-way, be attached to
any public property, street light, or utility pole, except those signs erected
and maintained pursuant to and in discharge of any governmental function, or
required by any law, ordinance or governmental regulation, or except by those
signs for which consent is given by the board of commissioners.
   (b)   Any violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of twenty-
five dollars ($25.00) to one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. No. 137-1987, 2-10-87)
   Editor's Note-Nonamendatory Ord. No. 137-1987, adopted 2/10/87 has been
codified herein at the discretion of the editor as § 19-10.
§ 19-11. CONTROL OF SILT AND MUD.
   (a)   All persons, firms, partnerships, corporations and other entities
shall not cause or permit silt or mud from any source to be emitted to any
public way or streets, storm sewer system or any silt control device, in such
amounts that create a hazard for traffic or pedestrians; or in any way create a
general nuisance.
   (b)   Any violation of paragraph (a) above shall constitute a misdemeanor
and be punishable by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day of violation shall constitute a
separate offense.
Ord. No. 023-1989, §§ 1, 2, 7-11-89)
   Editor's Note-Nonamendatory Ord. No. 023-1989, §§ 1, 2 adopted 7/11/89 has
been codified herein at the discretion of the editor as § 19-11.
Sec. 19-12. OWNERS TO MAINTAIN UTILITY STRIPS AND CUL-DE-SACS, AND DECORATE
STREET ISLANDS.
   All owners of lots or parts of lots in the city that front on streets or
alleys shall be responsible for maintaining the area within the street right-
of-way in front of their lots or parts of lots located between the sidewalk and
the curb and gutter or edge of roadway surface in the area commonly called the
utility strip, cul-de-sacs and decorative street island containing an area of
vegetation. It shall be unlawful for the owner or owners of such lots or parts
of lots that front on utility strips, cul-de-sacs or decorative street islands
to permit any weeds, grass or plants, other than approved trees, to grow to a
height exceeding twelve (12) inches in the utility strip, cul-de-sac or
decorative street islands. It shall be unlawful for the owner or owners of such
lots or parts of lots that front on utility strips, cul-de-sacs or decorative
street islands to permit a nuisance as defined in section 11-3 declared a
nuisance, to be maintained or kept thereon in the utility strip, cul-de-sac or
decorate street island.
Ord. No. 023-1993, 3-23-93)
Secs. 19-13--19-25. RESERVED.
ARTICLE II. STREET LIGHTING*
   *Cross references-Electrical code, §
6-61 et seq.; electric service, §
23-141 et seq.
Sec. 19-26. SCOPE.
   All lighting poles, supporting bases for mounting poles, luminaries, and
arms and brackets for supporting luminaries installed within the city limits
shall meet the requirements of this article.
(Ord. No. 6-D-83, 7-26-83)
Sec. 19-27. JURISDICTION.
   All street lights in the city shall be under the full jurisdiction and
control of the electric department, other than those areas served by other
utilities than the city. The department is empowered to make rules and
regulations in addition to those regulations presently in effect and enacted by
the city commission. The department shall have the authority to enforce the
rules and regulations and it may determine necessary rules and regulations to
successfully operate the system. No installation of new street lights shall be
approved unless permission is given by the board of commissioners.
(Ord. No. 01-1984, 1-24-84; Ord. No. 006-1990, 2-13-90)
Sec. 19-28. MINIMUM STANDARDS.
   (a)   Where the installations are for the sole purpose of street lighting,
poles shall be aluminum composition of sufficient height to provide a twenty-
five (25) foot mounting height of the luminaire. Wood poles whose primary
purpose is for other utility distribution (electric, telephone, etc.) may have
street lighting arms, brackets and luminaries mounted on them as a secondary
use only. However, prior approval from the city shall be required before any
street lighting may be allowed to be mounted to these wood poles.
   (b)   Poles may be either concrete base mounted or direct burial if located
on either a local or collector street. Poles located on an arterial street
shall be concrete base mounted only.
   (c)   The type of luminaire to be used shall be based on the classification
of the street on which a street light is located:
      (1)   Local streets. Streets that are classified as local streets shall
use one hundred (100) watt (nine thousand five hundred (9,500) lumens) high
pressure sodium vapor luminaries.
      (2)   Collector streets. Streets that are classified as collector streets
shall use either one hundred (100) watt (nine thousand five hundred (9,500)
lumens) or two hundred fifty (250) watt (twenty-seven thousand five hundred
(27,500) lumens) high pressure sodium vapor luminaries as determined by the
supervisor of the electric department.
   The determination will be based on the amount of traffic or hazardous
conditions that may exist and the amount of residential development at that
location. If a two hundred fifty (250) watt luminaire is required the developer
will be duly notified.
      (3)   Arterial streets. Streets that are classified as arterial streets
shall use two hundred (250) watt (twenty-seven thousand five hundred (27,500)
lumens) high pressure sodium vapor luminaries or larger as determined by the
supervisor of the electric department.
Street classification is to be determined according to the standards and
diagrams contained in the subdivision regulations and community development
plan.
   (d)   The arms for supporting the luminaries shall be four (4) feet for the
one hundred (100) watt and six (6) feet for the two hundred fifty (250) watt.
   (e)   Specifications for the poles, construction of the concrete base,
luminaries and supporting arms are attached to and made a part of this article
and copies of the specifications will be maintained in the city clerk's office
and by the planning commission staff office.
(Ord. No. 6-D-83, § A, 7-26-83)
Sec. 19-29. PROCEDURES FOR INSTALLATION ACCORDING TO UTILITY SERVICE AREA
JURISDICTION.
   (a)   Areas served by the city. For areas served by the city, all street
lighting shall be installed by the developer at his own expense and in
accordance with the city's specifications.
   (b)   Areas served by Blue Grass R.E.C.C. For areas within the city limits
served by Blue Grass R.E.C.C., the city will authorize in writing Blue Grass
R.E.C.C. to furnish and install all street lighting in accordance with their
standards and policies which may exceed but may not be less than the city's
minimum standards.
   (c)   Areas served by Kentucky Utilities. For areas within the city limits
served by Kentucky Utilities, the city will authorize in writing Kentucky
Utilities to furnish and install all street lighting in accordance with their
standards and policies, which may exceed but may not be less than the city's
minimum standards.
(Ord. No. 6-D-83, § B, 7-26-83)
Sec. 19-30. COSTS FOR STREET LIGHTING WHEN INSTALLED IN EITHER BLUEGRASS
R.E.C.C. OR KENTUCKY UTILITIES SERVICE AREA JURISDICTIONS.
   (a)   Regardless of which utility jurisdiction that street lights are
installed in, the developer shall pay the city for each unit installed.
   (b)   The developer may pay the city in either of the following methods:
      (1)   The city may be paid in advance for all installation costs at a
rate per unit to be determined when the planning commission approves the final
subdivision plat for the development.
      (2)   Payment may be deferred until street lighting installation is
required and authorized by the city at a later date. If this method is selected
by the developer, installation costs at a rate per unit will be determined when
the street lights are authorized by the city.
   (c)   A unit consists of a pole, concrete supporting base, anchor bolts,
luminaire complete with lamp and photo electric control, bracket, either a four
(4) or six (6) foot arm for supporting the luminaries and all wire and labor to
install the unit.
   (d)   The rate per unit will be determined according to utility jurisdiction
and in the following manner:
      (1)   Areas served by Blue Grass R.E.C.C.: The rate per unit will be
determined by the city based upon actual costs per unit figures for labor and
material submitted to the city by Blue Grass R.E.C.C.
      (2)   Areas served by Kentucky Utilities: The rate per unit will be
determined by the city based upon actual cost per unit figures for labor and
material submitted to the city by Kentucky Utilities.
(Ord. No. 6-D-83, § C, 7-26-83)
Sec. 19-31. PROPERTY OF UTILITY SERVING AREA.
   Street lights are the property of and shall be maintained by the utility
serving the area in which the street lights are located.
(Ord. No. 6-D-83, § D, 7-26-83)
Sec. 19-32. ENFORCEMENT.
   Enforcement of this article shall be as specified as Article 4 of the
subdivision regulations.
(Ord. No. 6-D-83, § E, 7-26-83)
Sec. 19-33. APPROVAL OF DEVIATIONS.
   Any deviation from the terms of this article shall first have approval of
the city commission.
(Ord. No. 6-D-83, § F, 7-26-83)
Sec. 19-34. TRUCK ROUTES.
   (a)   All commercial trucks traveling within the city limits of the city
shall be required to travel through and within the city upon the following
streets, except where the point of origination or destination reasonably
requires the usage of a street or streets other than the designated truck
routes, which are as follows:
      (1)   U.S. 27 By-pass (in its entirety);
      (2)   Main Street, from its intersection with U.S. 27 By-pass at the
south end and then in a northerly direction to the intersection at John Watts
Drive;
      (3)   Sulphur Well Road from its intersection with Main Street (near the
Courthouse) in a south-eastern direction to the city limits;
      (4)   North Third Street (KY 169) from its intersection with West Maple
Street northwest to the city limits;
      (5)   West Maple Street from its intersection with Main Street (at the
courthouse) southwest to the city limits;
      (6)   Etter Drive from U.S. 27 (By-pass) to North Third Street (KY 169);
      (7)   KY 169 to Oak Street to Main Street then north on Main Street to
Richmond Avenue (KY 169) in easterly direction to city limits.
(Ord. No. 309-1999, 10-14-99)
ARTICLE III. PEDESTRIAN, SAFETY; PEDESTRIANS APPROACHING VEHICLES OR BEING UPON
MEDIAN, PROHIBITED
Sec. 19-40. Definitions.
   As used in this section:
   Arterial roadway. Any arterial roadways listed in §
19-43  of this Article.
   Pedestrian. Any person afoot or in wheelchair.
(Ord. 1072-2019, 9-23-19)
Sec. 19-41. Prohibitions.
   (a)   No person shall cross an arterial roadway at any place except in a
crosswalk. Where there is no crosswalk, a person shall cross only at
intersection in which traffic control signal or other devices are in place.
Where the is no crosswalk nor traffic control signals or devices, a person
shall cross an arterial roadway only at an intersection.
   (b)   No person, other than a person in or on a vehicle, shall be upon an
arterial roadway or, while upon an arterial roadway, approach a vehicle, except
on that is legally parked at the curb or shoulder.
   (c)   No person shall be upon a median of an arterial roadway unless in the
process of legally crossing the roadway in a crosswalk, it is prima facie
evidence of a violation of this subsection if a person stay on the median
through two consecutive opportunities to cross the roadways in a legal manner
under this chapter and the traffic laws of the Commonwealth of Kentucky. The
exception found in Sec.
19-42(a) shall not apply to those pedestrians who stay on the median through
two consecutive opportunities to cross.
(Ord. 1072-2019, 9-23-19)
Sec. 19-42. Exceptions.
   Sections
19-41(b) and (c) of this article shall not apply to:
   (a)   Any person legally crossing the roadway;
   (b)   Any person engaged in law enforcement or rescue activities, including
providing assistance to an injured or disabled vehicle or person;
   (c)   Any person entering a stopped vehicle as an invited passenger where it
is lawful to do so, including accessing taxicabs or public transportation; and
   (d)   Any person engaged in emergency repair or maintenance activities of a
vehicle.
(Ord. 1072-2019, 9-23-19)
Sec. 19-43. Arterial roadways.
   (a)   The following roadways, which carry the most traffic within the City
of Nicholasville are arterial roadways for the purpose of this section:
Asbury Drive       Imperial Way                      Peachtree Drive
Barnes Street      Industrial Parkway                Rarrick Ave
Beauford Place     John C. Watts Drive               Rebel Road
Bell Court         John Sutherland Drive             Richmond Ave
Bristol Ave        Keene Road                        Ridgewood Drive
Broadway Street    Keene Center Drive                Ross Street
Brown Street       Kimberly Heights Drive            Shannon Parkway Shun Pike
Chestnut Street    Lake Street                       Southbrook Drive
Churchill Crossing Longview Drive                    Stratton Ave
Commerce Drive     Maple Street                      Strawberry Lane
Duncan Street      Martin Luther King Blvd           Third Street
East Brannon       Miles Road                        U.S. 27
Edgewood Drive     Natchez Trace                     Village Parkway
Elm Street         North and South Main Street (U.S. Walnut Street
                   27 X)
Etter Drive        North Plaza Drive                 Wichita Drive
Hickory Hill Drive Oak Street                        Williams Road
High Street        Orchard Drive                      
 
   (b)   This section shall also apply to the first two hundred (200) feet of
any roadways that intersects with an arterial roadway, as measured from the
point where the roadway and the arterial roadway intersect.
   (c)   That the appropriate Departments of the City of Nicholasville shall
annually review the list of arterial roadways found in Sec.
19-44 and provide recommendations to the City of Nicholasville concerning any
roadways that it believes, in the interest of pedestrian safety, should be
added to or removed from the list of arterial roadways found therein.
(Ord. 1072-2019, 9-23-19)
Sec. 19-44 Penalty.
   It is a misdemeanor for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to
perform any act required in this chapter. Unless another penalty is expressly
provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the
traffic regulations shall be subject to a fine or not less that twenty-five
dollars ($25) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00).
(Ord. 1072-2019, 9-23-19)

Chapter 21 TAXATION*
Art. I.   In General, §§ 21-1–21-15
Art. II.   Occupational License Fee, §§ 21-16–21-50
