ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 21-1. USE OF COUNTY ASSESSMENT ROLLS.
   (a)   The city, in accordance with KRS 132.285, does hereby elect to use the
county annual tax assessment for property situated within the city limits as a
basis for ad valorem tax levy upon order or approval by the city commission.
   (b)   In order to comply with the county assessment date, the city
assessment date shall revert to January 1, 1975, instead of April 1, 1975, and
shall continue each January first on succeeding years thereafter.
   (c)   In order to finance the costs of using the county's assessment there
is hereby appropriated from the budget item "General Fund" such monies as are
prescribed by KRS 132.285.
(Code 1972, § 19-3)
Sec. 21-2. ASSESSMENT OF INTEREST, PENALTY AND COSTS FOR DELINQUENT CITY TAX
BILLS.
   (a)   Assessment generally. For taxable periods after 2007, with the
exception of tax period 2019, after October 31 of each year, all delinquent ad
valorem taxes for that taxable year shall be assessed a penalty of ten percent
(10%) of the amount due. For tax period 2019, after November 30, all delinquent
ad valorem taxes shall be assessed a penalty of ten percent (10%) of the amount
due.
   (b)   Accrual of interest on delinquent tax hills. Beginning on January 1 of
the year following the taxable period of 2015, and all subsequent years
thereafter, with the exception of tax period 2019, all past due ad valorem tax
bills including the 10% penalty shall accrue interest at the rate of twelve
percent (12%) per annum until paid. For tax period 2019, beginning on February
1 of the year following the taxable period of 2019, all past due ad valorem tax
bills including the 10% penalty shall accrue interest at the rate of twelve
(12%) per annum until paid. All past due ad valorem tax bills for years prior
to January 2015 shall continue to be assessed interest, at six percent (6%) per
annum until paid.
   (c)   Collection: penalties and costs. On March 1 of each year, with the
exception of the tax period following taxable period 2019, all delinquent ad
valorem taxes for the previous taxable calendar year shall be given to the city
attorney for collection. For payments received on and after March 1, there
shall additionally be imposed a penalty of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per
bill or twenty-five percent (25%) of the then outstanding amount of the bill
including the ten percent (10%) penalty and any accrued interest, whichever is
greater, plus collection costs. For the tax period of 2019, these deadlines
shall be June 1 of the following year.
   (d)   Assessments, interest and costs to become a part of the tax bill. All
assessments, interest, penalties and costs shall become a part of the tax bill
and the lien created therein.
   (e)   Effective date. Subsection (a), (b) and (d) shall take effect and
become enforceable with as valorem taxes for the year of 1991 and subsequent
years thereafter division (c) shall apply to all unpaid 2002 tax bills and
subsequent years thereafter.
(Ord. No. 012-1991, §§ 1-5, 5-14-91; Ord. No. 438-2003, 2-13-03; Ord. No. 551-
2005, 8-30-05; Ord. No. 612-2006, 9-1-06; Ord. No. 669-2007, 8-6-07; Ord. No.
776-2009, 1-11-10; Ord. No. 922-2015, 8-17-15; Ord. No. 986-2017, 8-28-17; Ord.
No. 993-2017, 11-6-17; Ord. No. 1062-2019, 8-16-19; Ord. No. 005-2020, 3-19-20)
   Editor's note-Ord. No. 012-1991, §§ 1-5, adopted May 14, 1991, did not
specifically amend the Code; hence, its inclusion herein as § 21-2 is at the
discretion of the editor.
Sec. 21-3. Manner of billing and place and manner for payment of city tax
bills.
   (a)   Manner of billing. The 2019 tax bills will be mailed on or before
October 31. Bills for subsequent tax years will be mailed on or before
September 30th of each taxable calendar year to the mailing address on record
with the Jessamine County Property Valuation Administrator, the City shall not
be required to mail the tax bill to any other address, and the failure to do so
shall not provide a defense for late payment or nonpayment of as ad valorem
taxes. Taxpayers shall provide notice to the City Attorney of any change of
mailing address on record with the Jessamine County Property Valuation
Administrator during any taxable calendar year by mailing or hand delivering
said notice to 517 North Main Street, Nicholasville, Kentucky 40356.
   (b)   Place and manner for payment. Payment of ad valorem taxes shall be
mailed to P.O. Box 590, Nicholasville, KY 40340 or hand delivered to 601 North
Main Street, Nicholasville, KY 40356, and shall be postmarked or hand delivered
on or before the due date in order to be considered timely. The following forms
of payment shall be acceptable: cash; check or money order made payable to the
City of Nicholasville; or any of Visa, MasterCard or Discover. An additional
fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be collected for any returned checks.
(Ord. No. 986-2017, 8-28-17; Ord. No. 1062-2019, 8-16-19)
Secs. 21-4--21-15. RESERVED.
ARTICLE II. OCCUPATIONAL LICENSE FEE
Sec. 21-16. Definition.
   The word “city” shall mean the city of Nicholasville, Kentucky and/or
property held by ownership or lease or easement.
(Ord. No. 724-2008, 12-11-08)
Sec. 21-17. License required.
   Within the city limits it shall be unlawful for any person, company,
proprietorship, partnership or corporation to sell or offer for sale alcoholic
beverages without first having procured a license to do so and having paid the
required license tax therefor.
(Ord. No. 724-2008, 12-11-08)
Sec. 21-18. Administration generally.
   This article shall be administered by the tax administrator, under the
direction of the city commission.
(Ord. No. 724-2008, 12-11-08)
Sec. 21-19. License term.
   All licenses issued under this article shall be due on July 1 of each year,
and all licenses shall expire on June 30 of each year, succeeding the date
issued, except as hereinafter specified.
(Ord. No.724-2008, 12-11-08)
Sec. 21-20. Partial year license.
   When any person applies for a new license authorized to be issued by this
article, he shall be charged, if the license is issued, the full fee for the
respective license if six (6) months or more remain before the license is due
to be renewed and one-half (1/2) the fee is less than six (6) months remain
before the license is due to be renewed. No abatement of license fees shall be
permitted to any person who held a license of the same kind for the same
premises in the preceding license period and who was actually doing business
under the license during the last month of the preceding license period.
(Ord. No. 724-2008, 12-11-08)
Sec. 21-21. When fee payable.
   The amount of any license fee due under this article shall be payable at the
time that business commences in the city limits and before the first day of
July of each year thereafter.
(Ord. No. 724-2008, 12-11-08)
Sec. 21-22. Revocation, suspension.
   (a)   Any license issued under this article may, with notice to the holder
thereof, and after a hearing as provided in this article, be revoked or
suspended by the city commission:
      (1)   If any person is disorderly in, on or at the premises covered by
the license and disturbs the good order of the community or the license holder
suffers or permits any disorderly conduct in, on, or at the licensed premises;
or
      (2)   If the holder of the license shall misrepresent any material facts
in his return as to the kind of business or any other fact necessary or proper
to determine the amount of license tax to be paid.
   (b)   When the mayor has probable cause to believe that a license should be
revoked for any of the causes enumerated in this section, it shall be his duty
to refer charges against the holder of the license by filing a statement of
charges against the holder of the license with the city commission. The charges
shall be in writing and each charge shall be clearly set out.
   (c)   Within three (3) days after filing of charges with the city
commission, a notice of the filing of charges and of the time of a hearing
thereon shall be mailed to the licensee at the address shown on the license. A
hearing before the city commission shall be held within ten (10) days after the
filing of charges with the city commission. The evidence shall be transcribed
and the action and decision of the commission on the charges shall be reduced
to writing and recorded in the minute book.
(Ord. No. 724-2008, 12-11-08)
Sec. 21-23. Penalties.
   (a)   A penalty of ten percent (10%) of the tax due will be added to all the
taxes unpaid after June 30 of each year. Interest at the rate of one-half
percent (1/2%) per month will continue to accumulate until the fees are paid
plus any collection fees incurred to collect this tax.
   (b)   Each person who has not complied with the provisions of this article
prior to July 1 of each year shall be guilty of a Class D misdemeanor.
(Ord. No. 724-2008, 12-11-08)
Sec. 21-24. Civil remedies.
   In addition to the penalties provided in section 21-23 for a violation of
the provisions of this article, the fee may be collected from the person from
whom the same is due by a civil action in any court of competent jurisdiction
in the state. Recovery shall include court costs and reasonable attorney's fee
for the city's attorney.
(Ord. No. 724-2008, 12-11-08; Ord. No. 861-2013, 4-24-13)
Cross-reference–Alcoholic beverages, city license fees, §
3-11.
Secs. 21-25–21-50. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. [RESERVED]
Secs. 21-51–21-70. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. LICENSE TAX ON INSURANCE COMPANIES*
Sec. 21-71. Imposition.
   There is hereby imposed on each insurance company a license fee for the
privilege of engaging in the business of insurance within the corporate limits
of the city on a calendar year basis.
(Ord. No. 036-1984, § 1, 11-13-84; Ord. No. 017-1990, § 1, 4-24-90)
Sec. 21-72. Amount.
   (a)   The license fee imposed upon each insurance company which issues life
insurance policies on the lives of persons residing within the corporate limits
of the city shall be ten percent (10%) of the first year's premiums actually
collected within each calendar quarter by reason of the issuance of such
policies.
   (b)   The license fee imposed upon each insurance company which issues any
insurance policy which is not a life insurance policy or health insurance
policy shall be ten percent (10%) of the premiums actually collected within
each calendar quarter by reason of the issuance of such policies on risks
located within the corporate limits of the City of Nicholasville on those
classes of business which such company is authorized to transact, less all
premiums returned to policyholder; however, any license fee or tax imposed upon
premium receipts shall not include premiums received for insuring employers
against liability for personal injuries to their employees, or death caused
hereby under the provisions of the worker's compensation act and shall not
include premiums received on polices of group health insurance provided for
state employees under KRS 18A.225(2), and all other health insurance premiums.
(Ord. No. 036-1984, §§ 2, 3, 11-13-84; Ord. No. 017-1990, §§ 2, 3, 4-24-90;
Ord. No. 019-1990, 4-24-90; Ord. No. 1036-2019, 2-25-19)
Sec. 21-73. Due date; interest.
   All license fees imposed by this article shall be due no later than thirty
(30) days after the end of each calendar quarter. License fees which are not
paid on or before the due date shall bear interest at the tax interest rate as
defined in KRS 131.010(6).
(Ord. No. 036-1984, § 4, 11-13-84; Ord. No. 017-1990, § 4, 4-24-90)
Sec. 21-74. Annual report.
   Every insurance company subject to the license fees imposed by this article
shall annually, by March 30, furnish the city with a written breakdown of all
collections in the preceding calendar year for the following categories of
insurance:
      (1)   Casualty;
      (2)   Automobile;
      (3)   Inland marine;
      (4)   Fire and allied perils;
      (5)   Life.
(Ord. No. 036-1994, § 5, 11-13-84; Ord. No. 017-1990, § 5, 4-24-90)
ARTICLE V. FINANCIAL INSTITUTION FRANCHISE AND LOCAL DEPOSIT TAX
§ 21-80. IMPOSITION OF TAX.
   There is imposed on all "financial institutions", as defined in KRS Chapter
136, located within the corporate limits of the city, for the 1996 tax year and
all subsequent years, a franchise tax at the rate of 0.020% on all deposits, as
defined in KRS Chapter 136, maintained by such financial institutions.
(Ord. 183-1996, 10-10-96)
§ 21-81. TAX DUE.
   For transition purposes, the 1996 tax year will be treated differently in
terms of collection of taxes than for all subsequent years. For the 1996 tax
year, the following timetable is hereby established:
   (a)   The city will issue tax bills to financial institutions no later than
May 1, 1997. Payment of the tax shall be due with a two percent (2%) discount
by May 31, 1997, or without the discount by June 30, 1997; if not paid by June
30, 1997, a penalty of ten percent (10%) shall be charged thereafter and if
placed in the hands of the city attorney for collection a fee of twenty-five
percent (25%) of the total due shall be charged.
   (b)   For all tax years subsequent to the 1996 tax year, the following
timetable is hereby established:
   The city will issue tax bills to financial institutions no later than
December 1 of each year. Payment of the tax shall be due with a two percent
(2%) discount by December 31 of each year, or without the discount by January
31 of each year. If not paid by January 31 a penalty of ten percent (10%) shall
be charged thereafter and if placed in the hands of the city attorney for
collection a fee of twenty-five percent (25%) will be added.
(Ord. 183-1996, 10-10-96)
§ 21-82. LIEN IMPOSED.
   The city shall have a lien for taxes upon any and all property subject to
the tax imposed by these sections, which lien shall be superior to all
encumbrances prior or subsequent.
(Ord. No. 183-1996, 10-10-96)
§ 21-83. USE OF TAX.
   All moneys collected pursuant to these sections shall be paid into the
general fund of the city to be used for the payment of proper expenditures as
determined by the city commission.
(Ord. No. 183-1996, 10-10-96)
§ 21-84. PENALTY.
   All taxes due in accordance with these sections which are not paid before
June 30, 1997, for tax year 1996, or which are not paid before January 31, for
all subsequent years tax years shall be deemed delinquent and shall bear
interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per annum in addition to the plat
penalty and attorney fee provided in §§ 2 and 3. See §§
21-31.
(Ord. No. 183-1996, 10-10-96; Am. Ord. 303-1999, 8-26-99)
ARTICLE VI. TRANSIENT ROOM TAX
§ 21-85. IMPOSITION OF TAX.
   There is hereby imposed a tax of three percent (3%) on the rent for every
occupancy or a suite, room, or rooms, charged by all persons, companies,
corporations, or other like or similar persons, groups, or organizations doing
business as motor courts, motels, hotels, inns, “bed and breakfasts,” or like
or similar accommodations businesses.
(Ord. No. 991-2017, 10-9-17)
§ 21-86. DUE DATE.
   It shall be the duty of an entity described in §
21-85 doing business in the city to collect the tax and pay the same to the
city on a monthly basis with such payments being due and payable fifteen (15)
days after the end of each month commencing October 1, 2017, and continuing
each and every fifteenth day of every month thereafter.
(Ord. No. 991-2017, 10-9-17)
§ 21-87. INSPECTION OF BOOKS; RECORDS.
   The city is authorized to examine the books, papers and records of any
person, firm, organization or other like or similar accommodation business
required herein to file a return. Said examination shall be permitted in order
to determine the accuracy of any return made, or if no return was made to
determine the amount of room tax due and owing.
(Ord. No. 279-1998, 10-15-98; Ord. No. 991-2017, 10-9-17)
§ 21-88. Interest; penalty.
   (a)   Any tax imposed by this Article remaining unpaid after it becomes due
shall bear interest at the rate of twelve percent (12%) per annum simple
interest of the amount of the unpaid tax payable and added to the principal
amount when paid. A fraction of a month is counted as an entire month for
purposes of interest calculation.
   (b)   In addition to any other remedy provided at law or by the terms of
this Article, if said account remains unpaid fifteen (15) days after the due
date, then the city may pursue collection by a civil action in any court of
competent jurisdiction in the state. Recovery shall include court costs and
reasonable attorneys' fees.
   (c)   In addition to any other remedy provided at law or by the terms of
this Article, if said account remains unpaid sixty (60) days after its due
date. the city and/or the Joint Tourism Commission may seek criminal charges
through the Office of the Jessamine County Attorney for enforcement of this
Article.
   (d)   Any owner, manager. corporate officer. director, or agent in charge of
any facility subject to this Article is deemed responsible for seeing that said
tax is paid. Sixty (60) days delinquency on the part of any establishment
charged with collecting and paving this tax shall be prima facie evidence of
willful intent not to pay same.
   (e)   Upon conviction for willful intent not to pay said tax. any person
mentioned in division (d) above shall be guilty of a Class B misdemeanor as
defined in KRS Chapter 500 et seq. and upon conviction may be fined not more
than two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) or sentenced to imprisonment in
the County Jail for not more than ninety (90) days in said jail, or both fine
and imprisonment may be levied. Each day's continued violation shall constitute
a separate violation.
(Ord. No. 279-1998, 10-15-98; Ord. No. 991-2017, 10-9-17)

   Div. 1. Generally, §§ 22-70--22-72
   Div. 2. Wrecker Service, §22-73
   Div. 3. Vehicle Storage Facility, § 22-80

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
§ 22-1. SPECIFIC ORDINANCES SAVED FROM REPEAL.
   Nothing contained in this Code or in the ordinance adopting this Code shall
be construed as repealing or otherwise affecting any ordinance or other action
of the city commission regulating or restricting traffic or parking on specific
streets or in specific places.
(Code 1972, § 12-1) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
§ 22-2. POWERS, DUTIES OF CHIEF OF POLICE.
   The chief of police shall have and exercise all powers and duties in
relation to the management, direction and regulation of all traffic as provided
in this chapter and the enforcement of these regulations and may in cases of
emergency whenever he shall deem it advisable for the public safety or
convenience, temporarily close any street or part of any street to vehicular
traffic, or to vehicles of certain types, may divert the course of pedestrians,
or may temporarily prevent the parking or stopping of vehicles at any place in
the city.
(Code 1972, § 12-2) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
§ 22-3. AUTHORITY OF POLICE OFFICERS TO DIRECT TRAFFIC.
   Officers of the police department or such officers as are assigned by the
chief of police are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or
signal in conformance with this article and other traffic laws. In the event of
fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians,
officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require,
notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter and other traffic laws.
(Code 1972, § 12-3) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
   Cross reference-Police generally,
Chapter 15.
§ 22-4. AUTHORITY OF OFFICERS OF FIRE DEPARTMENT TO DIRECT TRAFFIC.
   Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or
assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity.
(Code 1972, § 12-4) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
   Cross reference-Fire department, §
8-21 et seq.
§ 22-5. DESIGNATION, USE OF SAFETY ZONES.
   The chief of police is authorized to designate and lay off safety zones at
places where the public safety and convenience require it. Such zones are to be
indicated by stands, or by lines on the street, or in some other visible and
suitable manner. It shall be unlawful to drive a vehicle within any safety zone
when the same is occupied and no vehicle shall be permitted to stop opposite
such safety zone except when actually taking on or discharging passengers or
merchandise.
(Code 1972, § 12-6) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
§ 22-6. ACCIDENTS-REPORTS REQUIRED.
   The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury or death
of any person or property damage shall immediately by the quickest means of
communication, either verbal or written, give notice of such accident to the
police department if such accident occurs within the city. The police
department may require any driver of a vehicle involved in an accident of which
report must be made as provided in this section to file supplemental reports
whenever the original report is insufficient in the opinion of such department,
and may require witnesses of accidents to render reports to such department.
(Code 1972, § 12-7) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
   State law reference-Authority to require accident reports, KRS 189.365.
§ 22-7. SAME-WHEN DRIVER UNABLE TO REPORT.
   Whenever the driver of a vehicle is physically unable to make the required
accident report and there was another occupant in the vehicle at the time of
the accident capable of making the report, such occupant shall make or cause to
be made such report.
(Code 1972, § 12-8) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 189.635.
§ 22-8. INTERFERING WITH VEHICLE.
   No person shall, without the permission of the driver or operator of a
vehicle, climb on, get in, or hitch onto a vehicle, or sound any horn or signal
device thereon, or attempt to manipulate any of the machinery of the vehicle or
set the same in motion, or interfere with such vehicle in any way.
(Code 1972, § 12-9) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-9. TIRES LIKELY TO DAMAGE STREETS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle, that has
corrugated metal tires, or tires with lugs or spikes, upon or over any street
of the city, except as herein provided. Any person desiring to move any such
vehicle over any of the streets of the city shall apply to the chief of police
and notify him of such intention and the time he wishes to move such vehicle,
and obtain a written permit to do so, which permit shall prescribe the route to
be followed in moving such vehicle and the time it is to be moved. It shall be
the duty of such person to move such engine or vehicle at the prescribed time
and to follow the route thus prescribed.
(Code 1972, § 12-11) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
   State law reference-Chains and lugs on wheels, KRS 189.190.
Sec. 22-10. CORNER CUTTING PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle, when approaching an
intersection, to make either a right or left turn and drive through a vacant
lot or a lot upon which is located any place of business, instead of making a
right or left turn at the intersection.
(Code 1972, § 12-12) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-11. BACKING.
   The driver of any vehicle shall not back the same unless such movement can
be made with reasonable safety and without interfering with other traffic and
at no time shall a vehicle be backed around a corner.
(Code 1972, § 12-13) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-12. DRIVING, RIDING ON SIDEWALKS.
   No person shall operate, ride, lead or drive any vehicle or animal upon any
sidewalk, except in crossing the same, nor shall any person cause any such
vehicle or animal to remain stationary on any sidewalk.
(Code 1972, § 12-14) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-13. BICYCLES PROHIBITED ON SIDEWALKS.
   No person shall ride a bicycle on any sidewalk in the city.
(Code 1972, § 12-14) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-14. DRIVING OVER HOSE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to run any vehicle upon, or over any
firehose, except with the permission of the fire department officer in charge.
(Code 1972, § 8-9) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-15. TRUCKS; RESTRICTED TRAVEL ON CERTAIN STREETS.
   (a)   No truck shall travel on any street or on any portion of any street
which is designated by the Board of Commissioners of the city as being
prohibited to through truck traffic. This prohibition shall not apply to trucks
which have a destination on the designated street or on the designated portion
of any street, noncommercial vehicles, vans, step-vans, recreational vehicles,
pickup trucks, or trucks which are owned or operated by the city or the
Jessamine _________.
   (b)   Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be subject
to a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than one hundred
dollars ($100.00) for each offense.
(Ord. No. 294-1999, 4-8-99) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Secs. 22-16--22-30. RESERVED.
ARTICLE II. PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING*
   *State law reference-Parking regulations, KRS 189.430 et seq.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 22-31. PARKING OF TRUCKS AND OTHER RELATED VEHICLES AND EQUIPMENT.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any owner or person to park or cause to be
parked any truck commonly designated and referred to as a two (2)-ton truck or
higher weight capacity, boats, trailers, recreation vehicles, camper or any
other vehicle commonly used by the motoring public, on the streets of the city
for an overnight period or for a period not to exceed two (2) successive hours
unless the driver is engaged in an off-street commercial practice.
   (b)   Violation of this section may result in a fine as prescribed in the
Code of Ordinances. Additionally, the provisions of Sec.
22-35 are also applicable and may be enforced by any police officer or peace
officer of the Commonwealth of Kentucky. Any owner of a vehicle described in
subsection (a) shall be responsible for the payment of any unpaid fines and
court costs if not paid within ten (10) days of written notice to owner to the
address as shown on the vehicle registration and shall be deemed sufficient for
the purpose of the written notice.
(Ord. No. 7-E-79, 7-3-79; Ord. No. 067-1985, 1-14-86; Ord. No. 281-1998, 12-10-
98; Ord. No. 458-2003, 7-17-03; Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-32. VEHICLES INTERFERING WITH STREET CLEANING.
   In order to facilitate the work of cleaning and sweeping the streets, it is
hereby made the duty of any person having in his control any vehicle of any
kind to promptly move such vehicle out of the way of the street cleaning
apparatus of the city when requested by the person operating such apparatus.
(Code 1972, § 12-27) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-33. PARKING BACKED TO CURB.
   No vehicle shall be backed up to a curb.
(Code 1972, § 12-29) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-34. PARKING VIOLATIONS FINES.
      (a)   For the following offenses:
      (1)   Parking in front of or within five (5) feet of a fire hydrant,
there shall be a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00);
      (2)   Parking against a yellow line, there shall be imposed a minimum
fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00);
      (3)   Parking in a no parking zone, which is prohibited by signs or other
visible indicators, a minimum fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00);
      (4)   Parking in a fire lane in either a public street or public parking
lot, there shall be a minimum fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00);
      (5)   Double parking, there shall be a minimum fine of twenty-five
dollars ($25.00);
      (6)   Blocking a driveway, either public or private, or entrance to any
public or private property, there shall be imposed a minimum fine of twenty-
five dollars ($25.00);
      (7)   Parking in a designated parking space for persons with disabilities
either on a public street or a public parking lot, shall be imposed a minimum
fine of fifty dollars ($50.00);
      (8)   Parking in such a way as to block an accessory ramp for persons
with disabilities shall impose a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00);
      (9)   Parking against traffic-This is parking in such a manner that the
parked car is opposite the flow or line of traffic. There shall be a minimum
fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
      (10)   Parking of trucks and other related vehicles and equipment, there
shall be a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00);
      (11)   Parking of vehicles in a manner that interferes with street
cleaning, there shall be a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00);
      (12)   Parking backed to curb, there shall be a fine of twenty-five
dollars ($25.00);
      (13)   Parking violations fines, there shall be a fine of twenty-five
dollars ($25.00);
      (14)   Parking ineligibly in a handicapped space, there shall be a fine
of fifty dollars ($50.00).
   The above described fines are minimum fines and shall be subject to a
maximum fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) each.
(Code 1972, § 12-30; Ord. No. 06-1984, 3-13-84; Ord. No. 011-1992, 8-11-92;
Ord. No. 377-2001, 7-17-01; Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-35. TOWING OR IMMOBILIZATION OF UNLAWFULLY PARKED VEHICLES.
   Any vehicle left parked continuously in any of the two (2) hour parking
zones in the city for more than four (4) hours is subject to being towed away
by the police department. All costs of the removal of the vehicle shall be
borne by the owner of the vehicle, before same may be returned after towing.
(Ord. No. 3-D-80, 3-18-80; Ord. No. 377-2001, 7-17-01; Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-
08)
Secs. 22-36--22-50. RESERVED.
DIVISION 2. ABANDONED VEHICLES*
Sec. 22-51. PROHIBITED; PRESUMPTION.
   Any person who leaves a vehicle upon a public road under circumstances
indicating an abandonment, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. A vehicle left
upon a public road for forty-eight (48) consecutive hours shall be presumed to
be abandoned.
(Code 1972, § 12-60) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-52. IMPOUNDMENT, SALE.
   The city police shall cause any vehicle under §
22-51 which is fit for future use to be removed by some person engaged in the
business of storing or towing motor vehicles and the provisions of KRS 376.275
shall apply in disposing of such vehicle. Any money obtained in disposing of a
vehicle that is in excess of any liens shall be paid by the seller to the owner
and if the owner cannot be located, the excess money shall escheat to the state
pursuant to the provisions of KRS Chapter 393. Such vehicle shall be registered
or transferred in the county where the sale is conducted upon an affidavit by
the seller that the provisions of KRS 376.275 have been met. The affidavit
shall contain information as prescribed by the state department of revenue.
(Code 1972, § 12-61) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-53. DISPOSITION OF UNFIT VEHICLES.
   If any abandoned vehicle is, in the opinion of the chief of police, unfit
for future use, the chief of police may dispose of it immediately in such
manner as he deems appropriate.
(Code 1972, § 12-62) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Secs. 22-54--22-65. RESERVED.
DIVISION 3. JUNKED, UNLICENSED VEHICLES*
   *Cross reference-Nuisances generally,
Chapter 11.
   State law reference-Similar provisions, KRS 189.751.
Sec. 22-66. JUNKED, INOPERATIVE VEHICLES PROHIBITED; EXCEPTIONS.
   (a)   All owners or occupants of property shall keep the same and the city
street adjacent to their property clear of old, unused, stripped, or junked
automotive vehicles or trailers of any kind or type not currently in operating
condition, or not properly licensed pursuant to KRS 186.020.
   (b)   This division shall not apply to historic motor vehicles, registered
and licensed in conformance with KRS 186.043, and property zoned so as to
permit such a use, or to motor vehicles in sheltered storage.
(Code 1972, § 12-66) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-67. NOTICE OF VIOLATION; TIME LIMIT FOR COMPLIANCE.
   It shall be the duty of the administrator of occupational license and tax
environmental control to serve or cause to be served a notice upon the owner or
occupant of any premises upon which the vehicle is permitted to remain in
violation of this provision of this division and to demand the removal thereof
or conformance with the provisions of this division within seven (7) days on
private property, seventy-two (72) hours on city street or public property.
(Code 1972, § 12-67; Ord. No. 074-1986, 2-25-86; Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
Sec. 22-68. SERVICE OF NOTICE.*
   *Cross reference-Nuisances, generally,
Chapter 11.
   Notice shall be served upon persons by certified mail, regular mail,
personal notification via phone or in person, but if the whereabouts of such
persons is unknown and the same cannot be ascertained by the public officer in
the exercise of reasonable diligence the public officer shall make an affidavit
to that effect, and the serving of such notice upon such persons may be made by
publication in the newspaper of general circulation for two (2) consecutive
days. A copy of such shall be posted in a conspicuous place affected by the
notice and it shall be recorded in the office of the city clerk.
(Code 1972, § 12-68) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
§ 22-69. REMOVAL BY CITY.
   If the persons so served do not comply with the provisions of this division
within seven (7) days private property or seventy-two (72) hours on city street
or public property, the city government may proceed to remove the vehicles,
keeping an account of the expenses of removal and such expenses shall be
charged to and paid by owner of the vehicle.
(Code 1972, § 12-69) (Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08)
ARTICLE III. WRECKER SERVICE VEHICLE STORAGE FACILITY
DIVISION I. GENERALLY
§ 22-70. TITLE; PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this article is to provide the city and police department
personnel with safe, efficient and equitable system for the removal of damaged,
disabled, abandoned, illegally parked, or where a vehicle or its driver is
involved in illegal activity from city streets. All applications, fees, lists,
complaints, or other written information concerning the administration of this
section shall be maintained and monitored by the chief of police, under the
direction and supervision of the city commission. All requests by police
personnel for wrecker and/or storage facility services within the city, shall
be administered through the police department as directed herein.
(Ord. No. 810-2011, 8-1-11)
Sec. 22-71. Removal of wrecked or disabled vehicles.
   (a)   Preference calls.
      (1)    The owner or lawful operator of a damaged or disabled vehicle
shall generally have the right to determine the wrecker service to be summoned
and the destination of said vehicle. The police officer in charge of the
accident or disabled vehicle shall honor the motor owner/operator's preference
and take reasonable steps to carry out the notification of the appropriate
wrecker service, unless in the opinion of the police officer, the request is
either contrary to accepted police practices or would create a risk to the
general public.
      (2)   If, in any case, the police officer believes that an alternative to
the owner or operator's preference is necessary in order to protect the general
public or promote legitimate police matters, then the police officer shall act
in accordance with his/her training and skill by selecting an alternative
method of removal and/or site for storage.
      (3)   In any event, the police officer must advise the telecommunicator
of all pertinent information necessary for each towed vehicle. The
telecommunicator will record the relevant information concerning the wrecker
service and storage facility utilized in each incident in the “wrecker tow log”
maintained in the telecommunications office.
      (4)   No owner, employee, or agent for any wrecker service summoned to
the scene of an accident or disabled vehicle shall participate in, or
influence, the decision of the owner/operator as set out in subsection (1) of
this section.
   (b)   Non-preference calls. Where the motor vehicle operator is injured,
unavailable or otherwise indicates no preference for the destination of a
wrecker service, then the telecommunicator shall contact a wrecker service.
(Ord. No. 810-2011, 10-1-11)
DIVISION 2. WRECKER SERVICE
Sec. 22-73. Wrecker service list.
   (a)   Wrecker services shall provide twenty-four (24) hour service seven (7)
days per week, and shall respond to all emergency calls within fifteen (15)
minutes or less. In addition, the wrecker service must have a local telephone
number to handle emergency calls on a twenty-four (24) hour basis. Wrecker
services will limit phone numbers to one (1) primary phone number.
   (b)   The wrecker must have a minimum weight of one (1) ton, be equipped
with a motor driven winch, and otherwise meet standard wrecker specifications
as may hereafter be determined by the City Commission from time to time. In
addition, the wrecker must be equipped with one (1) ABC fire extinguisher,
safety chains, broom, and shovel. The wrecker service is responsible for
cleaning all debris from streets and property disposing of same when called to
the scene of an accident.
   (c)   The wrecker service must provide a copy of their identification card
through Kentucky Department of Transportation, Division of Motor Carriers. The
wrecker service must have lighting appropriately to be distinguished from other
vehicles. Each wrecker service must be capable of towing imported vehicles not
designed to be towed by conventional methods.
   (d)   The wrecker must impose a reasonable agreed charge for towed and
transported vehicles. (See
Appendix A). Wrecker services are prohibited from charging more for services
rendered pursuant to this article than they would charge for identical services
to private customers. Wrecker services shall further notify the city of any
intended increases in wrecker service charges at least thirty (30) days prior
to and after the City Commission has granted permission to the implementation
of those new charges.
   (e)   The wrecker service shall have personnel available during reasonable
business hours to provide information to the city and vehicles owners, owner's
agency or representative concerning the transportation of storage of towed
motor vehicles and their release.
   (f)   The wrecker service shall be responsible for all losses, theft, or
damages to vehicles from the time they are towed until the vehicle is released
to the owner, a dealership, auto repair, or storage facility.
   (g)   The wrecker service shall provide a secured inside and outside storage
with an alarm system for vehicles that may require holding for processing, or
other special needs, and if a vehicle held on the impoundment lot, no per day
cost will be added to the towing bill when it is being held at the request of
the Police Department.
   (h)   The wrecker service shall employ only those operators holding a valid
Kentucky Operator's license without conditions or restrictions that would
impair the driver's ability to operate wrecker equipment (see
Appendix C), and shall not sublet any wrecker services to any third parties.
   (i)   Any wrecker service contacted by the police department must provide
the city with certificates of insurance insuring said wrecker service against
theft, vandalism, personal injury, damages or other casualty losses in amounts
and on such terms as are prescribed by the Kentucky Department of
transportation. Said insurance shall provide coverage for the wrecker, the
towed vehicle and storage lot. The wrecker service must provide the city with
annual renewals of said insurance and the insurance policy must show the city
as an additional insured.
   (j)   The wrecker service must furnish an adequate record system for all
motor vehicles and property towed and stored, and adequate storage for all
personal property if removed from vehicle.
   (k)   Said record shall contain information including but not limited to, a
log indicating vehicle description (make, model, license, VIN number, color,
etc.), along with the date and time of the wrecker service on each call for
service. A copy of this record must be turned into the Chief of Police by the
first day of every month. (See
Appendix B).
(Ord. No. 810-2011, 8-1-11)
DIVISION 3. VEHICLE STORAGE FACILITY
§ 22-80. VEHICLE STORAGE FACILITY LIST.
   (a)   The wrecker service must have its own storage facility. The storage
facility must meet the city planning and zoning specifications for storage of
vehicles within a specified area.
   (b)   Inclusion of wrecker service and their storage facilities on service
list shall not be construed as an employment or contractual relationship
between the city and said business or facility, and the city assumes no
liability by virtue of this article for damages claimed by vehicle owners, or
any and all other persons who may present a claim for damages against the city
in connection with the towing, repair and/or storage of a motor vehicle.
(Ord. No. 471-2004, 1-29-04; Ord. No. 699-2008, 5-15-08; Ord. No. 710-2008, 7-
7-08)

APPENDIX C
Wrecker Service Requirements and Restrictions
      (1)   If the gross combined weight rating (GCWR) of the tow truck and its
towed vehicle is 26,001 pounds or more, and the towed vehicle alone exceeds
10,000 pounds gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR), then the driver needs a Group
A CDL. If the GVWR of the tow truck alone is 26,001 pounds or more, and the
driver either (a) drives the tow truck without a vehicle in tow, or (b) drives
the tow truck with a towed vehicle of 10,000 pounds or less GVWR, then the
driver needs a Group B CDL. A driver of a tow truck or towing configuration
that does not fit either configuration description above, requires a Group C
CDL only if he or she tows a vehicle required to be placarded for hazardous
materials on a "subsequent move," i.e., after the initial movement of the
disabled vehicle to the nearest storage or repair facility.
      (2)   All owners and operators must submit to the chief of police a
legible color copy of their valid Kentucky Operator's license prior to towing
for the Police Department. Furthermore, an operator cannot have a DUI (Driving
under the Influence of intoxicants) conviction within the past 12-month period
nor can an operator have had two (2) DUI convictions within the last 60-month
period. Neither an owner nor operator can have any felony convictions, nor can
they have any serious misdemeanor convictions within the previous five (5)
years that may be detrimental or discredit the reputation of the Nicholasville
Police Department or the City of Nicholasville. Determination of what
constitutes serious misdemeanor offenses will be determined by the chief of
police.

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
§ 23-1. SYSTEMS CONSOLIDATED.
   The city-owned electric transmission and distribution system, the city-owned
waterworks and distribution system, and the sanitary sewerage system and its
sewage treatment and disposal plant, are hereby combined and consolidated and
shall constitute a single combined and consolidated utilities system of the
city.
(Code 1972, § 20-1)
§ 23-2. ZONING VIOLATIONS NOT TO BE SERVED.
   No permanent connections of electricity, water or sewer service shall be
made to any building which is in violation of any of the provisions of the
zoning ordinances of the city.
§ 23-3. MANNER OF DISCONTINUING SERVICE.
   Whenever any utility service is discontinued, it shall be shut off or
disconnected at the curb or pole and the meter for that service shall be
sealed.
(Code 1972, § 20-4)
§ 23-4. DAMAGING, INTERFERING WITH WATER, SEWER AND ELECTRICAL FACILITIES.
   Any person who shall molest, damage or interfere with any system of
waterworks, sewers or electrical supply in the city, or the pipes, mains,
hydrants, wires or any part thereof, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(Code 1972, § 20-5)
   State law reference-Criminal damage to property, KRS Chapter 512.
Secs. 23-5--23-10. RESERVED.
ARTICLE II. METER SPECIFICATIONS
§ 23-11. METERS REQUIRED.
   (a)   All connections to the municipal water or electrical systems shall be
installed and connected with meters, which meters shall be furnished by the
city and remain the property of the city.
   (b)   All meters belong to the city, and consumers obtain no property rights
in the same by making the service deposit required. All meters are to be
installed and removed by employees of the city.
(Code 1972, § 20-17, 20-18)
   Cross reference-Tap fee for fire hydrant meters, §
23-31.
§ 23-12. METER SPECIFICATIONS.
   (a)   Meter Setters. Meter setters for 3/4" service shall be AWWA 5/8" x 3/
4" with brace eye, cutoff, check value at the meter outlet, and all purpose
fittings (brass). Meter setters for 1" services shall have brace eyes, cutoff,
check value at the meter outlet, and all-purpose fittings (brass). Meter
setters for 1 1/2" and 2" services shall be for 1 1/2" and 2" flanged meters
and shall have brace eyes, key value inlets, angle check value outlets, bypass,
and female iron pipe inlets and outlets, bypass, and female iron pipe inlets
and outlets. It shall be necessary to contact the appropriate utility for the
type of meter setter to be used for services larger than 2". All meter setters
shall be as manufactured by the Ford Meter Box Company, Inc., Wabash, Indiana
or Mueller Co., Decatur, Illinois. The riser height shall be sufficient to
place the meter within 24 inches of the meter vault lid.
   (b)   Meter Vaults.
      (1)   Boxes. The boxes for meter vaults shall be polyethylene with an
inside diameter of 18 inches for 3/4' single services, 24 inches for 1" and
duplex services, 30 inches for 1 1/2" services, and 36 inches for 2" services.
It shall be necessary to contact the appropriate utility for the type of meter
vault to be used for services larger than 2". Extension rings shall be required
for all boxes larger than 18 inches in diameter.
      (2)   Cover and lid. The cover and lid shall be cast iron with standard
pentagon bolt as manufactured by the Ford Meter Box Company, Inc., Wabash,
Indiana, Catalog No. C32 or equal if located outside of the City of
Nicholasville service territory; Catalog No. C32-T with 1 3/4" hole for single
3/4" services within the City of Nicholasville service territory; and Catalog
No. C32-TT with two 1 3/4" holes for double meter settings within the City of
Nicholasville service territory. Cast iron flat top covers and lids shall be
used only at locations specifically approved by the City of Nicholasville for
replacements of existing covers and lids and shall be as manufactured by Vestal
MFG, Sweetwater, Tennessee.
   (c)   Location of Meter Vaults.
      (1)   Residential. Water service lines and meter vaults shall be
installed at the approximate mid-point of each front property line at finish
grade utilizing a single meter setting for single family dwellings and a double
meter setting for duplexes for lots with street frontages greater than fifty
(50) feet. Double meter settings may be installed on common lot lines for lots
with street frontages of 50 feet or less.
      (2)   Commercial and industrial. It shall be necessary to contact the
appropriate utility for the location of meter vaults and water service lines on
commercial and industrial lots.
      (3)   Meter vaults shall be installed a minimum of four (4) feet
horizontally from the distribution main but shall not extend more then twenty
(20) feet beyond the street right-of-way. They shall not be located and/or
installed in parking lots, driveways or sidewalks.
(Ord. No. 330-2000, 4-13-00)

Sec. 23-22. Wastewater user charges.
   (a)   Purpose. It is determined and declared to be necessary and conducive
to the protection of the public health, safety, welfare and convenience of the
city to collect charges from all users who contribute wastewater to the city's
treatment works. The proceeds of such charges so derived will be used for the
purpose of operating and maintaining the public treatment works.
   (b)   Definitions. Unless the context specifically indicated otherwise, the
meaning of terms used in this section shall be as follows:
      BOD (denoting Biochemical Oxygen Demand). The quantity of oxygen utilized
in the biochemical oxidation or organic matter under standard laboratory
procedure in five (5) days at 20oC, expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l).
      Commercial user. All retail stores, restaurants, office buildings,
laundries, and other private business and service establishments.
      Debt service. Charges levied on users of the wastewater treatment works
to support the annual debt service obligations of the system.
      Governmental user. Includes legislative, judicial administrative, and
regulatory activities of federal, state and local governments.
      Industrial user. A source of indirect discharge which does not constitute
a "discharge of pollutants" under regulations issued pursuant to § 402 of the
Clean Water Act.
      Institutional user. Includes social, charitable, religious, and
educational activities such as schools, churches, hospitals, nursing homes,
penal institutions and similar institutional users.
      Normal domestic wastewater. Wastewater that has a BOD concentration of
not more than 300 mg/l, a suspended solids concentration of not more than 350
mg/l, an ammonia nitrogen concentration of not more than 30 mg/l, and/or an
oil/grease (total) concentration of not more than 100 mg/l.
      Operation and maintenance. Those functions that result in expenditures
during the useful life of the works for materials, labor, utilities and other
items which are necessary for managing and for which such works were designed
and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes replacement as
defined below.
      Replacement. Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment,
accessories or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the
treatment works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works
were designed and constructed.
      Residential user. Any contributor to the city's treatment works whose
lot, parcel or real estate, or building is used for domestic dwelling purposes
only.
      Shall. Is mandatory; May is permissive.
      SS (denoting Suspended Solids). Solids that either float the surface of
or are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids and which are removable
by laboratory filtering.
      Treatment works. Any devices and systems for the storage, treatment,
recycling and reclamation of municipal wastewater, domestic wastewater or
liquid industrial wastes. These include intercepting sewers, outfall sewers,
wastewater collection systems, pumping, power, and other equipment and their
appurtenances; extensions, improvements, remodeling, additions and alterations
thereof, elements essential to provide a reliable recycled supply such as
standby treatment units and clear well facilities; and any works, including
site acquisition of the land that will be an integral part of the treatment
process or is used for ultimate disposal of residues resulting from such
treatment (including land for composting sludge, temporary storage of such
compost and land used for the storage of treatment wastewater in land treatment
systems before land application); or any other method or system for preventing,
abating, reducing, storing, treating, separating or disposing of municipal
waste or industrial waste, including waste in combined storm water and sanitary
sewer systems.
      Useful life. The estimated period during which a treatment works will be
operated.
      User charge. That portion of the total wastewater service charge which is
levied in a proportional and adequate manner for the cost of operation,
maintenance and replacement of the wastewater treatment works.
      Water meter. A water volume measuring and recording device, furnished
and/or installed by a user and approved by the city.
   (c)   Revenue fund.
      (1)   The revenues collected, as a result of the user charges levied,
shall be deposited in a separate non-lapsing fund known as the revenue fund,
from which disbursements shall be made to the operation and maintenance fund;
wastewater renewal, replacement and extension fund; capital projects fund; and
other reserved funds in accordance with the covenants and provisions of the
existing municipal revenue bond indenture and other applicable ordinances.
      (2)   Fiscal year-end balances in the referenced funds shall be used for
no other purposes than those designated. Monies which have been transferred
from other sources to meet temporary shortages in said funds shall be returned
to their respective accounts upon appropriate adjustment of the user charge
rates for operation, maintenance and replacement. The user charge rate(s) shall
be adjusted such that the transferred monies will be returned to their
respective accounts within six (6) months of the fiscal year in which the
monies were borrowed.
   (d)   Sewer rates.
      (1)   Rates and charges based on the surcharge method.
      (2)   Volume charges for residential customers are based upon the average
monthly metered water consumption for the previous winter quarter period
(months of December, January and February). Volume charges for other than
residential customers are based upon one hundred (100) percent of the months
metered water usage.
      (3)   Sewer rates shall be effective as follows:
Inside city monthly service charge (bills due in August, 2022):

      (4)   If a residential, commercial, institutional, or industrial user has
a consumptive use of water, or in some other manner, uses water which is not
discharged into the wastewater collection system, the user charge for that
contributor may be based on readings of a wastewater meter(s) or separate water
meter(s) installed and maintained at the user's expense.
      (5)   Any person who transports septic tank, seepage pit or cesspool
contents, liquid industrial waste or other batch liquid industrial waste or
other batch liquid waste and wishes to discharge such waste at the Jessamine
Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) shall first have a valid Waste Hauler
Permit. All applicants for a Waste Hauler Permit shall complete the application
form, pay the appropriate fee and receive a copy of the city's regulations
governing the discharge of liquid wastes from septage hauler trucks. All
persons receiving such permits shall agree, in writing to abide by all
applicable provisions of their waste hauler permit. The WWTP Superintendent
will certify the capacity of each tank before issuance of a waste hauler
permit.
      The discharge of all hauled wastewater wastes must be performed at the
Jessamine Creek WWTP on normal working days (Monday through Friday) 6:45 a.m.
to 3:45 p.m. A Hauled Wastewater Discharge Manifest certifying the origin of
all waste must accompany each load. Hauled wastewater is subject to sampling at
the discretion of WWTP staff based on information recorded on the Manifest. All
monitoring/testing costs will be billed to the Waste Haulers as described
hereinafter.
      The Hauled Wastewater Discharge Manifest must contain the following:
Hauler (Company Name), Permit Number, Gallons of Waste, Generator Waste,
Address of Generator of Waste, Date & Time Loaded, Hauler's Signature, Date &
Time Disposed of at WWTP and WWTP Operator's Signature. Failure to accurately
record every discharge or falsification of data will result in revocation of
the waste hauler permit or be fined not more than one thousand dollars
($1,000.00) for each occurrence.
      Fees: Annual Per Truck Discharge Permit $50.00
The Septic Waste Discharge Rate will be set by the Director in recognition of
industry accepted cost of service principles and prevailing market conditions.
      Waste Haulers will be billed by the City of Nicholasville through
miscellaneous invoicing once per month. Provided a sight glass is mounted in
the middle of a truck's tank, the capacity of the tank will be deemed either
half of a load or a full load.
   (e)   Express surcharge rates.
      (1)   For those users whose wastewater has a greater strength than normal
domestic wastewater, a surcharge in addition to the normal user charge, will be
collected.
      (2)   The following surcharge rates shall apply to each user of the
treatment works that contributes sewage in excess of the maximum allowable
concentrations referenced herein.
 
Parameter Surcharge Rates
BOD       $0.318 per pound
TSS       $0.365 per pound
NH3-N  $0.795 per pound
 
      (3)   Method of billing surcharges - the excessive strength surcharge
shall be based on the following formula, with the total applied to the monthly
bill of affected users:
      Formula
      (A(D-300)+B(E-350)+C(F-30))(.00834)(G) = Surcharge Payment ($/Mo.)
      Where formula components are as follows:
      A.   Surcharge rate for BOD, in $/pound.
      B.   Surcharge rate of SS, in $/pound.
      C.   Surcharge rate for NH3-N in $/pound.
      D.   User's average BOD concentration, in mg/l.
      E.   User's average SS concentration, in mg/l.
      F.   User's average NH3-N concentration, in mg/l.
      G.   User's monthly flow to wastewater works, per 1,000 gallons. No
reduction in wastewater service charges, fees, or taxes shall be permitted
because of the fact that certain wastes discharged to the wastewater works
contain less than 300 mg/l of BOD, 350 mg/l of SS or 30 mg/l of NH3-N.
   (f)   The city clerk shall maintain financial records to accurately account
for revenues generated by the treatment system and expenditures for operation
and maintenance of the system, including normal replacement costs.
   (g)   The director of public utilities shall review not less often than
annually the wastewater contribution of users, the total cost of OM&R of the
wastewater works, debt service obligations, and user charge rates. Based on
such review, the director shall revise, when necessary, the schedule of user
charge rates to accomplish the following:
      (1)   Maintain an equitable distribution of OM&R costs among users of the
treatment system; and
      (2)   Generate sufficient revenues to offset costs associated with the
proper operation and maintenance of the treatment works and to meet debt
service requirements.
      (3)   Excessive strength and toxicity surcharges shall be reviewed at the
time of and in conjunction with the review of user charges. Surcharge rates
shall be revised where necessary to reflect current treatment and monitoring
costs.
      (4)   Each user shall be notified, at least annually, in conjunction with
a regular bill of the rate and that portion of the total charge which is
attributed to OM&R of the treatment works.
   (h)   Billing, penalty.
      (1)   All users shall be billed monthly. Payments shall be due by the
tenth day of the month. Any customer not rendering payment by the tenth day of
the month shall be considered delinquent.
      (2)   A late payment penalty of ten (10%) percent of the user charge bill
will be added to each delinquent bill for each billing cycle. When any bill is
more than eleven (11) days in default, water and/or wastewater service to such
premise shall be disconnected until such bill is paid.
(Ord. 160-1996, 4-4-96; Am. Ord. 316-1999, 12-14-99; Ord. No. 679-2007, 11- 14-
07; Ord. No. 1060-2019, 8-12-19; Ord. No. 049-2021, 7-26-21; Ord. No. 083-
2022, 6-27-22)
Sec. 23-23. Electric rates.
   (a)   Generally. The new rate schedules are adopted as follows for
residential service, commercial services, large commercial services and general
services, and security lighting services and shall be effective with bills due
and payable in August, 2022:
      (1)   Residential service:
         a.   Availability. Residential service shall be provided to
residential customers in single-family dwelling units when electric service
supplied to the dwelling unit is used for household purposes and is metered
through one (1) meter. If a portion of the electric service supplied to a
dwelling unit is used for nonresidential purposes, and the customer can arrange
wiring in such a manner that the electric service for residential purposes and
nonresidential purposes can be metered separately, this rate schedule is
applicable to the portion used for residential purposes. If not separated then
billing shall be made as a commercial service.
         b.   Type of service. Single-phase, 60 hertz, 120/140 volts.
         c.   Monthly rate:
            1.   Service charge: $11.00.
            2.   Energy charge: $0.08219 per kwh.
            3.   Minimum bill: Service charge plus the energy charge for kwh
used.
         d.   Power cost adjustment charge. Charges for electric service under
this schedule shall be subject to provisions of the power cost adjustment
clause.
      (2)   Commercial service:
         a.   Availability. To customers for electric power and energy
requirements. Each premises will be supplied at one (1) point of delivery, and
all service supplied will be measured through one (1) meter. Availability at
this schedule is subject to the service policies of the city.
         b.   Type of service. Single- or three-phase at the option of the
city, 60 hertz at one (1) of the city's available service voltages of 120/240
volt single-phase, 120/208 volt three-phase, or 120/240 volt three-phase.
         c.   Monthly rate:
            1.   Service charge: $15.00.
            2.   Energy charge:
                  i.   First 250 kwh, $0.10920 per kwh.
                  ii.   Next 1,750 kwh, $0.09991 per kwh.
                  iii.   All over 2,000 kwh, $0.09219 per kwh.
            3.   Minimum bill: Service charge plus the energy charge for kwh
used.
         d.   Power cost adjustment charge. Charges for electric service under
this schedule shall be subject to the provisions of the power cost adjustment
clause.
      (3)   Large commercial service:
         a.   Availability. Available to nonresidential customers with a
monthly demand in excess of 20 kw, subject to the service policies of the City
of Nicholasville, for a period of not less than twelve (12) months where
service is supplied at one point of delivery and measured through one meter.
Not available for temporary, standby, breakdown, supplementary, or resale
service.
         b.   Type of service. Single-or three-phase at the option of the city,
60 hertz, at one of the city's available service voltages of 120/240 volt
single-phase, 120/208 volt three-phase, 120/240 volt three-phase, or 277/480
volt three-phase.
         c.   Monthly service.
            1.   Service charge:       $55.00.
            2.   Energy charge:
               i.   First 10,000 kwh, $0.06747 per kwh.
               ii.   Next 90,000 kwh, $0.06434 per kwh.
               iii.   All over 100,000 kwh. $0.06434 per kwh.
            3.   Demand charge: $7.50 per kw billing demand.
            4.   Minimum bill: The sum of the service charge, the energy
charge, and the demand charge.
         d.   Billing demand. The billing demand will be the average demand
delivered to the customer during the fifteen (15) minute period of maximum use
during the month.
         e.   Primary voltage service. When the customer owns and maintains all
equipment, except metering, necessary to take service at the city's primary
service voltages, a discount of $0.15 per kw of billing demand shall be applied
to the demand charge.
         f.   Power cost adjustment charge. Charges for electric service under
the schedule shall be subject to the provisions of the power cost adjustment
clause.
      (4)   General service.
         a.   Availability. Available to nonresidential customers with a
monthly demand in excess of 450 kW, subject to the service policies of the City
of Nicholasville, for a period of not less than twelve (12) months where
service is supplied at one point of delivery and measured through one meter.
Not available for temporary, standby, breakdown, supplementary, or resale
service.
         b.   Type of service. Single-or three-phase at the option of the city,
60 hertz, at one of the city's available service voltages of 120/240 volt
single-phase, 120/208 volt three-phase, 120/240 volt three-phase, or 277/480
volt three-phase.
         c.   Monthly service.
            1.   Service charge   $110.00
            2.   Energy charge:
               i.   First 10,000 kWh   $0.06746 per kWh
               ii.   Next 90,000 kW   $0.05871 per kWh
               iii.   All over 100,000 kWh   $0.05871 per kWh
            3.   Demand charge   $10.00 per kW billing demand
            4.   Minimum bill. The sum of the service charge, the energy
charge, and the demand charge.
         d.   Billing, demand. The billing demand will be the average demand
delivered to the customer during the fifteen (15) minute period of maximum use
during the month.
         e.   Primary voltage service. When the customer owns and maintains all
equipment, except metering, necessary to take service at the city's primary
service voltages, a discount $0.15 per kW of billing demand shall be applied to
the demand charge.
         f.   Power cost adjustment charge. Charge for electric service under
the schedule shall be subject to the provisions of the power cost adjustment
clause.
      (5)   Security lighting service:
         a.   Availability. To residential and general service electric
customers of the city where overhead secondary facilities are readily available
for the lighting of private areas, in accordance with the service policies of
the city.
         b.   Type of service. Area lighting by means of a lamp installed in a
standard luminaire, controlled by a photo-electric relay, mounted with a
standard bracket on a wood pole and served by overhead facilities.
         c.   Monthly rate. If the lamp is installed on an existing city pole,
the monthly charge shall be as follows:
            Lumens      Monthly Charge per Lamp
            100W            $11.00
            250W            $14.00
            400W            $17.00
         d.   Additional facilities. When additional facilities are required,
the customer will, in addition to the above charges, pay the following: Each
additional pole and span wire at $1.50 per month. Other service and materials
at actual cost.
         e.   Power cost adjustment charge. Charges for electric service under
this schedule shall be subject to the provisions of the power cost adjustment
clause.
   (b)   Power cost adjustment clause charges (PCA). The above rate schedules
shall be subject to the power cost adjustment clause charges in addition to the
aforesaid rates. The power cost adjustment (PCA) is expressed as dollars per
kwh and is multiplied by the energy (kwh) sold during each billing period to
each customer’s usage. The PCA is designed to be calculated monthly based on
actual power costs and energy sales for the period. The following formula has
been designed to calculate the PCA:
      PCA = A/B - Base Rate where,
      PCA = The cost adjustment expressed as dollars per kwh to be multiplied
by the energy (kwh) sold during each billing period to customers on rate
schedules subject to the PCA.
      A = Actual expense for purchased power for the current period.
      B - Actual energy sales (kWh) for the current period from rates subject
to the PCA for the same period as “A” above.
      Base Rate = The base rate is the expense for purchased power, exclusive
of SEPA power cost, in the base period divided by energy sales in the base
period. The base rate reflects purchased power cost, expressed as dollars per
kWh, included in retail rates. The base rate effective July 1, 2019 is
$0.06685/kWh.
   (c)   Periodic adjustment of PC. Each period, the PCA formula is used to
calculate average purchased power costs per retail kWh sold and to determine
the adjustment to customer bills. If purchased power costs are lower than
estimated, the PCA is negative and customers receive a credit on their bill.
If, on the other hand, purchased power costs are higher than estimated, the PCA
is positive and customers receive an additional charge on their bill. The PCA
shall be adjusted at least annually to true up and over or under collection of
funds collected through the PCA.
   (d)   Determination of maximum billable load by including power corrected to
ninety percent (90%). The city reserves the right to place a KVA meter on
selected customer. The power factor will be determined by KW at time of peak
demand divided by KVA at time of peak demand.
      (KW, KVA = Actual power factor)
      KW  = P.F.
      KVA
KW billable will be adjusted as follows: KW at maximum demand x ninety percent
(90%) power factor divided by actual power factor equals billable KW.
      (KW x 90, Actual P.F. = adjusted KW)
      KW x 90 =  Billable KW)
      power factor
   The above calculation is used to adjust the billable KW demand only in the
months in which the power factor is below ninety percent (90%).
   The aforementioned formula will provide the city a method to recover its
additional power factor related costs in a manner similar to the method used by
the city's supplier, Kentucky Utilities.
(Ord. No. 1-F-83, § 3, 2-22-83; Ord. No. 052-1985, §§ 2, 3, 8-27-85; Ord. No.
105-1986, §§ 2, 3, 7-8-86; Ord. No. 219-1988, 10-25-88; Ord. No. 733-2009, 5-
15-09; Ord. No. 1061-2019, 8-12-19; Ord. No. 084-2022, 6-27-22)
Sec. 23-24. Responsibility for temporary electric service facility; inspection
fee.
   The city shall henceforth not construct or install any temporary electric
service for any construction project. It shall be the sole responsibility of
the builder or contractor to provide such construction according to all current
electrical codes employed by the city. It hereby shall be the duty of the
builder or contractor to pay the inspection fee for service received prior to
hookup, to the official electrical inspector of the city. Construction of the
temporary service facility shall be in accordance with specifications set forth
and adopted by the city. The builder or contractor shall pay the sum of fifteen
dollars ($15.00) as a temporary service connection fee which shall entitle the
applicant to temporary electric service for construction providing same has
been approved by the electrical inspector.
(Ord. No. 4-A-80, 4-8-80)
Sec. 23-25. When bills due.
   Monthly bills for water, sewer or electrical service will be due the tenth
of the month following billing.
(Code 1972, § 20-27)
Sec. 23-26. Person responsible for payment of bills.
   Charges for utility services furnished by the city shall be due from the
occupants of the premises, provided that upon application by the owner of any
premises who is not the occupant filed with the city clerk, the bills for such
use and service of the electrical, water and sewerage systems may be rendered
to the owner.
(Code 1972, § 20-28)
Sec. 23-27. Water tapping fees and capital assessments.
   (a)   Water tapping fees and the applicable RR&E portion as hereinafter
described is as follows:
Meter Size Tap fees RR&E Portion
Meter Size Tap fees  RR&E Portion
3/4"       $800.00   $650.00
1"         1,000.00  725.00
1-1/2"     2,000.00  1,450.00
2"         3,000.00  2,125.00
3"         6,000.00  5,450.00
4"         10,000.00 9,300.00
6"         20,000.00 19,150.00
8"         40,000.00 39,000.00
10"        60,000.00 58,850.00
12"        88,000.00 86,700.00
 
   (b)   The above fees include the meter and setting of meters for taps 2
inches in size, or smaller. For taps 3 inches in size, or larger, the costs
related to the meter and the setting of the meter shall be borne by the
applicant. The applicant will be responsible for having a licensed contractor
make the tap and install the necessary service lines, meter boxes and
appurtenances, subject to supervision by the city.
   (c)   An applicant for water service shall present evidence of a valid
building permit, prior to the issuance of a water tap. Water taps issued by the
city shall be in accordance with the schedule of fees as described herein, and
shall remain effective for as long as the building permit, as presented by the
applicant, remains effective.
   (d)   In the event that any building permit becomes void as a result of
inactivity or failure to construct in accordance with applicable building
regulations and zoning ordinances, then tap fees paid for said property shall
be forfeited in favor of the city.
   (e)   All revenues derived from the RR&E portion of the fees described
hereinabove, shall be deposited in a reserved, sinking fund to be known as the
renewal, replacement and extension fund (RR&E Fund). The RR&E Fund shall be
used to provide reasonable reserves for renewals, replacements, improvements,
extensions, and extraordinary major repairs of backbone water transmission
mains and water treatment plants, or any other valid capital expenditure as
determined by the Board of Commission.
   (f)   Any individual or entity applying for water service outside of the
city's corporate limits, shall be required to first request permission from the
board of commission prior to connecting to the city's system.
   (g)   Any person tapping a water line belonging to the city without its
consent or permission, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to
a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00).
   (h)   The city may impose a capital assessment on owners of property for
which the city has installed water mains and appurtenances, in which the city
has a cost basis. The amount of the assessment will be determined by the Board
of Commission upon consideration of the city's cost basis in the installed
improvements.

Sec. 23-28. Wastewater tap fees and capital assessments.
   (a)   City wastewater tap fees shall be eight hundred dollars ($800.00) per
unit.
   (b)   The applicant will have the installation made by a licensed contractor
subject to supervision by the city.
   (c)   An applicant for wastewater service shall present evidence of a valid
building permit, prior to the issuance of a wastewater tap. Wastewater taps
issued by the city shall be in accordance with the schedule of fees as
described herein, and shall remain effective for as long as the building
permit, as presented by the applicant, remains effective.
   (d)   In the event that any building permit becomes void as a result of
inactivity or failure to construct in accordance with applicable building
regulations and zoning ordinances, then tap fees paid for said property shall
be forfeited in favor of the city.
   (e)   All revenues derived from the fees described herein in excess of one
hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per unit, shall be deposited in a reserved,
sinking fund to be known as the renewal, replacement and extension fund (RR&E
Fund). The RR&E Fund shall be used to provide reasonable reserves for renewals,
replacements, improvements, extensions, and extraordinary major repairs of
wastewater interceptor sewers, wastewater treatment plants and lift stations,
or any other valid capital expenditure as determined by the Board of
Commission.

city's corporate limits, shall be required to first request permission from the
board of commission prior to connecting to the city's system.
   (g)   Any person tapping a wastewater line belonging to the city without its
consent or permission, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to
a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00).
   (h)   The city may impose a capital assessment on owners of property for
which the city has installed sewer mains and appurtenances, in which the city
has a cost basis. The amount of the assessment will be determined by the Board
of Commission upon consideration of the city's cost basis in the installed
improvements.

Sec. 23-29. Reconnect fees.
   All reconnect fees for city utilities shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00);
except for situations where consumers are reconnected due to a move from one
residence to another residence within the city limits, in which case such fee
shall then be ten dollars ($10.00).
(Code 1972, § 20-30; Ord. No. 10-D-79, 10-9-79; Ord. No. 038-1989, 10-10-89)
Sec. 23-30. Utility service deposits and refunds.
   (a)   Utility service deposits will be required or waived based upon the
credit report received from the credit agency as determined by the city at the
time that service is requested by the customer. If the customer has a
satisfactory credit report, the deposit may be waived. The amounts shown
hereinafter shall be due and payable to the city prior to a customer receiving
utility service. Deposits shall be required by the following customers:
   (b)   Utility service deposits shall be as follows:
      (1)   Residential class customers
 
All electric      $100.00
Electric with gas 50.00
Water             25.00
Sewer             25.00
 
      (2)   Commercial and industrial class customers
 
All electric      Two months average bill based on anticipated usage as
Electric with gas determined by analysis of consumption patterns of similar
Water             users or two months use for the premises where new service is
Sewer             sought as adjusted for measurable or estimated change.
 
   (c)   A refund of the utility deposit shall be made to the customer provided
said customer has a good payment history with the city after 12 consecutive
utility service billings. A good payment history shall be defined as the
customer not having more than three late payment penalties assessed during the
previous 12 consecutive billing periods. Utility service deposit refunds shall
be reflected as a credit on the customer's utility bill, beginning with the
next billing period following the establishment of a good payment history.
However this provision shall not apply to any commercial and industrial class
customers. Their utility service deposits shall not be refunded until their
utility service is discontinued.
   (d)   If the city cuts off utility service to any customer for any reason
and if said customer does not have a utility service deposit on account with
the city, the customer must pay a deposit to the city prior to restoring
utility service.

Sec. 23-31. Tap fee for fire hydrant meters.
   The city shall charge a tap on fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00)
for the placement of a water meter on any fire hydrant for private use. The
term of use of said meter shall not exceed a period of two (2) months. The
deposit will be refunded upon return of the meter. Failure to discontinue
service and return the meter to the city shall result in a forfeiture of the
deposit.
(Ord. No. 207-1988, 6-28-88)
   Editor's note-Ord. No. 207-1988, adopted June 28, 1988, did not specifically
amend the Code and at the discretion of the editor said provisions have been
codified herein as § 23-31.
